dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move across smoldering embers and reach a small grass fire. Dirt is thrown over the flames before a BOOT finish stamping them out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY GEIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're just lucky it didn't reach the trees... We move up two dirty pairs of overalls to find HENRY and GEIN sweating away as they continue shovelling out the flames. Both are in their forties and wearing flannel shi Ed wears an Elmer Fudd hat.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's gonna be a lot more jobs at that factory by Milwaukee come June. I could put in a word.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: You can't leave us, Henry. She needs both of us--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY GEIN
dialogues.text: Can you stop being a momma's boy for one second? Henry looks at Ed and he shrinks back.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to hurt you but Jesus you got to live your own life someday. That woman can take care of her own goddamn -- CLANG. Henry is hit by the shovel in the back of the head goes down. Ed steps slowly forward and puts down the shovel. The loo his face isn’t anger. It’s BLANK. He pulls at the flaps o his Elmer Fudd hat... then calmly walks away. The camera pans until we discover :

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: in his trademark black Mariani suit. He’s been watching t whole thing, standing in the smouldering field only a few feet away, holding a rose-patterned cup and saucer of tea (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a sip and turns to address the camera --

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Good evening. He places his cup daintily back on the saucer. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Brother has been slaying brother since Cain and Abel, yet even I did not see that coming. I was as blind-sided as poor Henry over there. He glances back over at the murder scene. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Apparently the authorities shared my naivete and believed the young man’s tale that Henry fell and hit his head on a stone and died of smoke asphyxiation. He shrugs: ‘Who would've thought it?’ ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Of course if they hadn’t believed him, Ed never would have had the opportunity to commit the heinous acts for which he became famous... and we wouldn’t have our little movie. Instead, we’d have more nice, safe, predictable ones like these...

dialogues.speaker: CLIPS
dialogues.text: from various Technicolor Films of the era: Peyton Place, Lana Turner and Betty Field. Pillow Talk with Doris Day a Rock Hudson. A Summer Place with Sandra Dee --

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Mere Technicolor baubles. He shudders with distaste. As if on cue the sky THUNDERS LOUDLY above him. He looks up and from behind the tree st produces an umbrella. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Ah. A bit of doom and gloom. Now, that’s more like it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hitch opens his brolly and the RAIN starts to bucket d we -- CcuT TO :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Equally torrential rain lit up by rotating KLEIG LIGHTS a they scan a MARQUEE: “WORLD PREMIERE! NORTH BY NORTHWEST. DIRECTED BY ALFRED HITCHCOCK.” JOSTLING CROWDS run the le of the block. SUPER: JULY 8, 1959. A PUDGY HAND discreetly squeezes a tiny, delicate one.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED AND ALMA HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Step out into a sea of FLASHBULBS. Hitch basks in the limelight while Alma, his razor-sharp, charming wife of o 30 years stands in the background, uncomfortable with all attention. Hitchcock’s agent LEW WASSERMAN, 45, dynamic, charismatic comes into view.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: This thing is going to be gigantic. I wish I had twenty percent of the take. Lew hustles them through the throng of REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS under their BLACK UMBRELLAS.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER ONE
dialogues.text: Does tonight's incredible reaction surprise you, Mr. Hitchcock?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: No, when I was planning North by Northwest I could already hear the screams and laughter. (then, to a BEAUTIFUL

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE FAN
dialogues.text: Any questions, my dear? The blonde fan, holding out her autograph book, shakes he head ‘no’ and giggles. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) A pity. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reporters crack up. Alma manages a polite smile as Le helps her into the limo, leaving Hitchcock alone for a mo to sign his autograph for the blond fan...

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER TWO
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, you've directed forty-six motion pictures. You host a hit TV show seen around the world. You’re the most famous director in the history of the medium... but you're sixty years old. Shouldn't you just quit while you're ahead?

dialogues.speaker: HOLDING ON HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: motionless and quietly devastated as FLASHBULBS CRACKLE o his face. The whiteness transforms into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GLEAMING WHITE TILES of a bathroom. We move past chro fixtures that evoke those in Spellbound and Psycho and ar at that same pudgy hand pouring CHATEAU CHEVAL BLANC '53 a cut crystal glass.

dialogues.speaker: HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: soaks in the tub. The champagne glass beside him, his corpulent frame is covered only by the London Times he's reading. Even in this deeply vulnerable state, he maintai the air of a haughty mischievous emperor. At the sound of a bedroom bureau being opened, Hitch’s ey shift to the FULL-LENGTH MIRROR on the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MIRROR
dialogues.text: We catch fleeting glimpses of Alma in a white half-slip a matching bra. She takes out some NYLONS and holds them up the light. Hitchcock watches enthralled. He puts down his glass and shifts a little in the tub, causing the water to lap agai the sides.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Alma pauses when she hears the small splashes. Neither up nor amused she continues about her business, taking a ski from the drawer. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Muhammad had the eyes of peeping Toms gouged out with arrows. Hitchcock clears his throat, rattling his paper as if he’ been reading the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Talking of arrows, did you read Mr. Weiler's review in the New York Times? Apparently, he found “the climax” to be -- and I quote -- “overdrawn.”

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I doubt whether Mr. Weiler has had a climax in years. Alma steps into her skirt as Hitch opens the London Times

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: And how about this little grenade? (reading) North by Northwest reminds us of Hitchcock's earlier, more youthfully inventive spy thrillers." (beat) And just to drive the nail into the coffin, there's a handy accompanying guide to the new masters of suspense. Hitchcock zeroes in on the photographs. They’re all young Thinner. And with hair. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Why do they keep looking for new masters of suspense when they still have the original?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Don’t be maudlin, you know how much it aggravates me. He catches his reflection in the mirror again and sinks further down into the water to hide his protruding belly. Alma comes in, takes the newspapers from him and puts the the side.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop reading them. You’ve been reading them for a week now. She puts down the TOILET SEAT and sits on it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes She moves (2)

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Tell me, dear. Am I really too old?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Yes. A true relic. And lest we forget, a notably corpulent one. over and kisses the top of his head.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: You always know precisely where to plunge the dagger, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Right between the shoulder blades. I learned it from your pictures. off to the mirror to apply lipstick and Hitchcock surreptitiously picks up the papers again... Alma steps

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Where are you off to?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I'm seeing Whit for brunch after I drop you off at the studio. Why don't you join us?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: We've just established that I'm too corpulent to be seen in broad daylight.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You'll feel better as soon as you find a project. Hasn’t Peggy unearthed any decent books yet?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Sleeping pills with dust jackets. back to inspect herself in the full-length mirror. Today's outfit is, we sense, rather more stylish than wha she would ordinarily wear.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Well? Hitch’s gaze never leaves the photo gallery of his younge rivals in the ‘New Masters of Suspense’ article...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Very presentable. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ON ALMA
dialogues.text: As she elegantly masks her hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Hurry up, darling. You're pruning. She leaves. Hitch grumbles and tosses his paper aside. He rises from the depths but suddenly loses his balance and grabs onto the SHOWER CURTAIN, wrenching it from the META RINGS on the rod. A GOD'S EYE view, looking down, as Hitchcock stares up at metal rings SPINNING NOISILY on the metal rod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FAMOUS MOUNTAIN TOP icon looms large. TWO GUARDS snap for the arrival of Hollywood royalty.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST GUARD
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock. Mrs. Hitchcock. Alma waves from the wheel of a GLEAMING BLACK 1957 CADILL Hitchcock sits next to her. He has his two SEALYHAM TERRI on his lap. He nods, awaiting more. FIRST GUARD (CONT’D) (to the dogs) Sirs. EXT. PARAMOUNT STUDIOS, PRODUCERS’ BUILDING - DAY The Cadillac pulls up. Alma notes Hitchcock’s look of frustrated envy as CREW MEMBERS bustle in and out of STAG 15. It's a hive of activity.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: There's a story out there waiting for you somewhere, Hitch. I promise. He gives her a good-bye peck and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t forget your lunch. Alma hands him a compact Fortnum & Mason basket and pats on his girth. He opens it to discover CELERY AND CARROT STICKS wrapped in Saran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luxurious, wood-paneled and very British. Hitch sits restlessly behind his desk, receiving his morning shave f his private barber, SILVIO. His longtime assistant, PEGGY ROBERTSON, 40s, crisp, British, fiercely protective of he boss, is going through a list of potential projects.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Fox is offering you The Diary of Anne Frank for the third time. Hitch directs his response to Silvio.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: The audience would spend the entire picture waiting for Miss Frank to discover the corpse I'd hidden in the attic. Wouldn’t you agree, Silvio?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIO
dialogues.text: Si. Hitch reaches for a carrot stick and CRUNCHES it.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: MGM wants you for the Ian Fleming book, Casino Royale, with Cary Grant. Definitely your style.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: (again, turning to Silvio) Doesn't she know I just made that movie? It's called North by Northwest. And “style” is merely self-plagiarism. Silvio nods, then recommences the shave. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I'm treading water, Peggy. I need something fresh. Something different. Without expensive stars like Cary Grant or Miss Kim Novak to pretty it up. Silvio unintentionally nicks Hitch’s face. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) A nice, clean, nasty little piece of work. Silvio hurriedly dabs away a speck of BLOOD. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I’ll see what I can find. Hitch motions for the barber to hold up the mirror. The i of his face overflows the small frame. Repulsed, he leans back his head and makes a hand motion for Silvio to SLIT THROAT.

dialogues.speaker: CONTAGIOUS LAUGHTER, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: INT. CHASEN’S RESTAURANT - DAY Alma lunches with screenwriter-novelist WHITFIELD COOK. “WHIT,” 50s, is Hitchcock's physical opposite -- dashing, razor-sharp and sophisticated. In fact he’d be at home in of his movies.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: ... Thank God I had a pocketful of pretzels. I was hiding in that props cupboard all night. (then) That’1l teach me to use a bedroom set instead of the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Serves you right. They laugh uproariously, quite at ease with each other.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hitch always said your private life was in danger of being more entertaining than any of your plots. He pours Alma another glass of wine, not remotely insulte

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: I can’t believe he let me have you all to myself for a whole afternoon. Especially looking this beautiful. He clinks her glass. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Trés chic. Alma turns to look at the menu again.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: All this relentless sycophancy is giving me indigestion. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a smile) What are you after? He laughs, his eyes straying to a PRETTY WAITRESS passing Alma notices.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And how is your wife?

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Elizabeth? (his eyes return to Alma) Over the moon since I promised her the dedication in my new novel. So what are you working on these days?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Hitch is going out of his mind looking for his next project. You know how unbearable he is when he doesn't have something lined up.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Almost as unbearable as when he does.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (laughing) Almost.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: I meant you. What are you working on?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I'm satisfied spending time in my garden.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: That is one lucky garden. Whit brings out a set of galleys and slides them across t tablecloth to her. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Actually, I was hoping you might be able to apply your considerable pruning skills to this. She looks down and reads the cover page. “Taxi to Dubrovn By Whitfield Cook.”

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Ah. All is finally revealed. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches her hand, affectionately. She brushes it away, affectionately...

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: The most fun I ever had was working with you. She looks through the opening pages... taking her time... enjoying making him wait...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I suppose I could give it a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock peeks avidly through the blinds at a smartly dressed KIM NOVAK-TYPE WOMAN hurrying along to some appointment or assignation... Hitch cranes to see who she meeting, but she moves tantalizingly out of sight. Hitch turns back with a sigh towards his desk, covered wi discarded newspaper clippings and boring story proposals. He sweeps them off his desk into the trash. INT. HITCHCOCK’S OUTER OFFICE - A MOMENT LATER A SHADOW looms over Peggy at her desk as she sifts throug another round of story ideas. It’s Hitchcock. He startles her.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Anything. Anything at all? He starts sifting through her tray. She notices the glass his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Nothing suitable. Is that water or do I need to call Alma? He drains it playfully.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Gin. Mother’s ruin. But something’s caught his eye. A circled review of Antho Boucher’s column “CRIMINAL MINDS” in the New York Times Review of Books. He picks it up. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Boucher says this “Psycho” book by Robert Bloch is ‘fiendishly entertaining’. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: It sounds ghastly. Everyone in town’s already passed.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: And who is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: The story department finished the coverage this morning.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Is this the one based on Ed Gein, the serial killer? He takes the coverage and reads for himself. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) “Graphic elements of brutal violence, voyeurism, transvestitism and incest.” Certainly not your average run of the mill nutcase, is he? He gives a grunt of approval.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Peggy. This is the boy who dug up his own mother.

dialogues.speaker: ON HITCH
dialogues.text: Completely engrossed as he sits reading “Psycho” in a cha by the fire of his elegant Bel Air home. He takes another gulp of wine when he hears Alma enter and slides the wine glass out of view. Alma pops her head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Famished. She disappears to take off her coat.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If you're good, maybe you can have a grapefruit later. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes back in again carrying some galleys, notices th title of Hitch’s book -- some trash called “Psycho.”

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whit gave me the galleys of his new book yesterday at lunch. I’ve already got some ideas on how you could adapt it. Hitch continues reading.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s elegant, sophisticated, full of intrigue --

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: The book or Mr. Whitfield Cook? She taps Hitch’s book dismissively with the galleys of “T to Dubrovnik.”

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: This might be the one, Alfred. He finally looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Leave it on the night stand. As she leaves she points to Hitch’s ‘hidden’ wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: There are calories in that, you know. But Hitch ignores her and turns to look out the window, h imagination starting to turn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed enters the bedroom. His mother, Augusta, is in the bed faced away from him.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: Aren’t you cold, ma? She doesn’t answer. We follow him to the dresser where he lingers a little too long over his mother’s open underwea drawer before grabbing the blue coverlet on the side. He comes over and spreads the extra blanket over her. Sti wearing his jacket, he takes off his shoes, gets into bed crawls up next to her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ED GEIN (CONT’D) Don't be afraid, ma... I’m here... As he puts his arm around her and pulls her close, we rev his mother’s ghoulishly embalmed face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slant of moonlight finds Alma fast asleep until a FINGE nudges her awake. She lifts her satin sleep mask to see Hitchcock holding out his copy of “Psycho.”

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Oh God. The look of obsession on his face is unmistakable.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Read the bit in the motel bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Now? He switches on the light by her bedside. She sits up, put her glasses and reads from the opened page.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Mary started to scream, and then the curtains parted further and a hand appeared, holding a butcher's knife. It was the knife that, a moment later, cut off her scream... and her head.” (handing him back the book) Charming. Doris Day should do it as a musical. She hands him back the book.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is nothing but low-budget horror movie claptrap. She turns off the light again and goes back to bed. A dee voice sounds from the darkness...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: But what if someone really good made a horror movie? EXT. HITCHCOCK’S GARDEN - MORNING The Hitchcocks eat breakfast on the terrace watching the GARDENERS trim the bushes and rake leaves from the pool. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Just think of the shock value. Killing off your leading lady halfway through. Alma can feel Hitch looking at her, waiting for a respons Clearly he isn’t going to let this one go. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) You're intrigued. Admit it. She butters her toast, casually taunts him by adding a la spoon of marmalade.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Actually, I think it’s a huge mistake. Hitch falls silent, a chastised schoolboy.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You shouldn't wait till halfway through... Kill her off after 30 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch enters with purpose, carrying a stack of photos and articles.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Peggy, I want you to summon your minions...

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Minions. Certainly. And who might they be...? Hitch heads for his office, in no mood for wise cracks. H spreads out the articles on the desk. Photos and magazine articles about Ed Gein...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Get them started buying copies of “Psycho.” Peggy stands in the doorway, watching --

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: How many do you need?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: All of them. I want every copy, nationwide. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have them scour every book shop and library. “Psycho” is my next picture, and I don't want anyone to find out the ending until they see it in the theater. Peggy shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: All that celery’s affecting your brain. She walks over, notices the LIFE MAGAZINE headline : “HOU OF HORRORS STUNS NATION.” Stark black and white photograp expose the nightmarish decay of the Gein house...

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you sure about this? This is so unlike you.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: That’s exactly the point, my dear. Peggy watches uneasily as Hitchcock pores over the articl with delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PIANIST plays a polite version of Al Jolson’s “My Mammy CLOSE ON A MANILA ENVELOPE clutched in one hand behind HITCHCOCK'S back as we follow him travel through the part The clink of champagne glasses as we reveal the GUESTS sa HELLO as he passes...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: And when the Wisconsin Police department raided his farmhouse in Plainview...

dialogues.speaker: HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Is now in position in front of the fire place. Around the coffee table are INVITED GOSSIP COLUMNISTS, including a H HOPPER-TYPE. They take in the gory LIFE MAGAZINE article. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (PRE-LAP) (CONT’D) ..they opened the door only to discover - voila... He produces the manila envelope from behind his back and empties THE HORRIFICALLY GORY CRIME SCENE PHOTOGRAPHS ins onto the coffee table. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +. Ten female heads with the tops sawn off, a dozen masks of human skin, and a pair of lips on a drawstring for a window shade. Hitch looks down sweetly at the circle of quietly horrifi expressions...

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER TYPE
dialogues.text: Is this really going to be you’re next picture, Mr. Hitchcock?

dialogues.speaker: HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: That is my intention, madam. Yes. Hitch taps the photo of ED GEIN.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I only wish he looked more like William Holden and less like Elmer Fudd. The other columnists scribble down the quote.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER TYPE
dialogues.text: Am I the only one who finds this offensive?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I was hoping everyone would. I mean life is deeply offensive and disgusting, isn’t it? Hitch glides off without missing a beat, past the Servers arriving with more hors d'oeuvres from the kitchen. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Try the finger sandwiches -- they’re real fingers. He snags a martini and collars Peggy while he’s at it. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Peggy. I’m going to need some research detailing a typical unmarried 30-year-old secretary from Phoenix, Arizona. He looks over at the pantry, where Alma can be glimpsed through the swinging door, putting food onto trays. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Her monthly rent, what she wears, what she reads, which scent or perfume she prefers... Hitch sees WHIT lean into view and innocently whisper something into Alma's ear making her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: .+. How she deals with a demanding boss when she’s trying to relax on her weekends off? Hitchcock doesn’t notice the joke. He now only has eyes o the pantry ahead. He forges on through the guests only to get waylaid by Le It is a classic Hitchcock moment, a character needing to someplace being held up by someone who wants to chat --

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: (re: the faces of the gossip columnists) I told you, Hitch. This thing’s strictly for the drive-in crowd. Hitch smiles tightly and extricates himself, heading on t the kitchen through more annoying guests --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit leans against the stove watching Alma expertly arran the next round of hors d'oeuvres coming in from the kitch

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Now, if this were a Hitchcock picture what would two characters like us, married to other people, be saying?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You don’t have to pretend you’re not upset he hasn’t read it yet, you know.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: I'm a big boy. I can take it.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Well, I loved it. What terrific fun it must have been to research.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Certainly more fun than reading those reviews. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) Do you think he really will read it? Suddenly, over Whitfield's shoulder, Alma sees Hitch loom in the doorway. Whit notes the tiny change in her eyes an turns. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Speak of the devil. Hitch stares blankly at him while Alma turns and busies herself over the sink, hiding an almost imperceptible blu WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) I have to admit, Hitch, I ran all over town looking for a copy of “Psycho” but couldn't find a single one.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I wonder how that could have happened. Hitch sips his martini, a picture of innocence. Then lean to Whit’s ear and whispers - just like Whit leaned into Alma’s ear a moment earlier. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Don’t stop looking on my behalf. Peggy appears in the pass-through, beckoning Hitch to hur back into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch returns to see the other GUESTS are now passing aro the GEIN PHOTOS. They look utterly confused and horrified a couple of them are even gathering their coats.

dialogues.speaker: ON LEW, PEGGY AND HITCH
dialogues.text: standing together watching.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: I’ve seen happier faces on a school bus going over a cliff.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I told you it would be too much.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: But they can’t stop looking, can they? He slurps his martini, sharing a smile with Lew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paramount President BARNEY BALABAN, 70s, ferocious, righteous, sits behind his impressive desk flanked by two CONSERVATIVELY-ATTIRED EXECUTIVES. Hitchcock and Wasserman sit across from them.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Audiences want to be shocked, Barney. They want something different. And this is it. He gestures to the untouched copy of “Psycho” in front of Balaban.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: The truth is, Hitch, every time you want to do something “different” like The Wrong Man or Vertigo, someone loses money. Hitchcock stares unblinking, giving nothing away.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: So we should stop trying to give them something new?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: You owe Paramount one last picture, Hitch. Can't you do something like North by Northwest but for us this time instead of for MGM? Hitch’s stare remains inscrutable. BARNEY BALABAN (CONT’D) We've offered you dozens of perfectly good properties.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: (imperiously) “Psycho.” Wasserman gives Balaban the same glacial stare. The Param executives shift uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: No one respects the name Hitchcock more than Paramount. But even a talented man sometimes backs the wrong horse. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Are you telling me “no?” Balaban maintains a calm, pleasant front.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: I think you know me better than that, Hitch. I would never say “no” to you. Hitch’s suppressed rage is building...but Balaban says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch and Lew walk down the stairs and through the leafy courtyard past Hitch’s office.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: What a putz. You know what his family did before they built those movie palaces? Ran a grocery store.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: My father ran a grocery store.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: Exactly. That's what I'm saying. He should show some respect. Hitch turns to Lew.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: They think I’ve lost my touch, Lew. My association with television has cheapened me.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: Are you referring to that deal I got you where Bristol-Meyers pays you twenty-nine grand an episode and you own the negative? That’s my kind of cheap.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: They just want the same thing over and over. They’ve put me in a coffin and now they’re nailing down the lid. Lew puts a comforting hand on him...

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: Hitch, I will never let that happen. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch doesn’t respond, Lew sensing the true depth of his friend’s melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much do you think you can make this picture for?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Eight hundred thousand... Give or take. Lew digests the figure...

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: I have whisky in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA does afternoon laps in the pool. A contemplative Hitchcock wanders down to the pool side wearing black sunglasses and a business suit. He watches Alma a moment. Finally she notices him.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You're back early. He shrugs, then sits at the table to pour himself a glass lemonade. Alma gets out and towels herself off.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm disappointed you didn't give Whit’s book a chance.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: He knows you well enough. She sits down next to him, noticing a tiny hole in her swimsuit. It’s starting to look a little threadbare.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Enjoy the pool now. We might not have it for that much longer. He looks off cryptically.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Why? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Paramount refuses to finance the movie. Imagine -- The studio that brought you Martin and Lewis and The Greatest Show On Earth considers Psycho distasteful. He brushes some fallen leaves off his chair. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Lew can’t find the money. Not quickly enough at least.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Why not wait? He doesn’t reply. She knows him well enough too and doesn question him further. She looks

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: We're going to have to go it alone, old girl. (beat) We'll finance the movie ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Are we going to have to sell the entire house or just the pool? at Hitch but he’s not joking. She turns to survey their beloved home and gardens. A long pause. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me and I won’t ever ask again. Why this one, Hitch? It’s not just because so many people are telling you 'no,' is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hitch? Without turning he takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Remember the fun we had when we started out and there was so little money and time? We took risks, we experimented. We invented new ways of making pictures because we had to. A long moment as he gazes across the pool. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I want to feel that kind of freedom again. He turns to look into her eyes for the first time. A glim of the real Hitchcock. Someone even his wife doesn’t see often...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The famous gates and the executive building beyond it.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Barney, we're about to propose a restructured deal for “Psycho”... INT. BALABAN’S PRIVATE OFFICE, PARAMOUNT - DAY Balaban watches Hitchcock and Lew closely. Hitchcock agai like a waxworks Buddha, revealing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: We finance it. Independently. Paramount only distributes it...in exchange for 40 percent of the profits.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: Interesting. But tell us, what exactly is Paramount distributing? Is this still a picture about a queer killing people in his mother’s dress?

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: What this picture is about is the reputation of Alfred Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: No-one’s arguing that.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: Barney, it’s very simple. This is Mr. Hitchcock’s next film. Are you in or are you out? A long silence.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: Well, obviously you have a lot of passion for this project. Let me talk it over with a few people internally and I’1l get back to you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: No. Now. Balaban takes in their inscrutable stares. Not unimpresse their chutzpah, he leans back and puts his hands behind h head, a king in his counting room.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: Fine. We’ll take that deal. If you can get the money... Finally, Hitchcock speaks up :

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: We've already got it, Barney. He pulls out his PERSONAL CHECKBOOK and opens it on the d Barney watches as Hitch takes the onyx fountain pen from mount. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Who do I make it out to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch and Alma lie side by side in their separate beds. A copy of “The Dance of Death” by Strindberg lies on Hitch’ bedside table. All traces of his bravado are gone...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: If this picture fails, Alma, we'll be in for a long, humiliating bout of crow- eating.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: The movie will be splendid.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Of the movie? Not in the least. But of you? Unquestionably. INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, PARAMOUNT - DAY PUDGY FINGERS part the slats of the blind. Hitch stares o hoping for some human moment to spy on. He’s restless... Peggy ushers JOSEPH STEFANO, 30s, into Hitch’s office.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH STEFANO
dialogues.text: Joe Stefano. Good to meet you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock leaves Stefano’s hand dangling in mid air and s down at his desk. JOSEPH STEFANO (CONT’D) Sorry I was late. My shrink session ran overtime. I see him every day and it’s still not enough.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I thought only director's assistants needed psychiatrists, not writers. Stefano laughs off the barb and takes a seat as Peggy sli out. The two men stare at each other but Stefano’s not remotel intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH STEFANO
dialogues.text: Do you see a shrink, Mr. Hitchcock? Hitch’s eyes follow a plume of cigar smoke curling up to ceiling...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: No. His gaze remains pointedly fixed on the ceiling. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I must say it boggles the mind to imagine what you and your “shrink” could possibly talk about daily.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH STEFANO
dialogues.text: The usual: sex. Rage. My mother. Hitchcock lowers his gaze, suddenly intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma sits with the Hitchcocks’ ACCOUNTANT who’s consultin ledger. She sits at her desk in the corner of the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: There's still the federal income tax payments... the property taxes... Not to mention the absence of any salary while he’s actually making the film...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Stop waffling, Donald. Give it to me straight. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Accountant takes off his glasses, plucking up the cou to look his favorite client in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: Hitch wasn’t exaggerating. If the film's a flop, you’re going to have to sell the house. Alma digests this.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Where do you suggest we cut?

dialogues.speaker: ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: Anywhere you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma’s moved to the kitchen table and is sorting through accounts herself, the dogs at her feet. Her face is now properly filled with concern. Hitch enters, holding out some typed pages. Alma covers h worry. He puts the pages on the table next to her.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I got Joe Stefano to write out the first few scenes. Why don’t you take a look? Alma takes Stefano's pages and starts to read...Hitch goe the fridge and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: We're about to have dinner. You don’t need anything else. He shuts the door. Leans against the fridge door. Hitch w but she gives nothing away...until she off-handedly place the pages on the table...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Well? She doesn’t look up...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Hire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a blank page being fed into a Corona typewriter. FINGERS pound out “PSYCHO” (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Hitchs step outside. The Cadillac is waiting. Alma follows him out and makes a final adjustment to his

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: The only thing worse than a visit to the dentist is one to the censor.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Whatever you do, Alfred, don’t lose your temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The intimidating plaque for the MPAA’s “PRODUCTION CODE ADMINISTRATION OFFICE” on the wall. Stefano’s TITLE PAGE is tapped angrily by GEOFFREY SHURLO 70s, the much-feared administrator for the Motion Picture Production Code. He sits at the head of a big table with ASSISTANTS. Sitting opposite are Hitchcock, Peggy and sev silent PARAMOUNT EXECUTIVES.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: The Code will absolutely not permit you to show a knife penetrating a woman's flesh.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I assure you, Geoffrey, my murders, are always models of taste and discretion.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: Is there any improper suggestion of nudity in this murder scene in the shower?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: She won't be nude. She’1l be wearing a shower cap. Shurlock makes a note. A man utterly devoid of any sense humor. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: We might accept a shot from outside the bathroom window with Marion in silhouette above the shoulders -- provided the glass is frosted. Hitch greets the suggestion with barely concealed contemp Shurlock turns the page.

dialogues.speaker: G EOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: Then -- this scene with the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: It’s completely necessary. Marion flushes evidence later found by her sister. It’s a clue to the girl’s disappearance.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: No American movie has ever found it “necessary” to show a toilet, let alone to flush it. Hitch turns to Peggy and a Paramount Executive.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Perhaps we ought to shoot the film in France and use a bidet instead? No response from Shurlock’s end of the room. Peggy stares down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, if this office denies you a seal, and we're certainly heading in that direction, your movie will not be released in a single theater in this country. Will you be making jokes then? Hitchcock gives a slow but meaningful shrug. GEOFFREY SHURLOCK (CONT’D) Good. Now why don’t we go all the way back to page two...

dialogues.speaker: ON HITCH
dialogues.text: boiling with rage as we hear the flurry of script pages - INT. PSYCHIATRIST’S OFFICE, BEVERLY HILLS - DAY Sunlight filters through sheer curtains revealing Hitchco trying his best to recline on an ANALYST’S COUCH. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Everyone in Hollywood resents me. I make them millions... and yet every year I sit at those dreadful award show dinners, waiting for them to say, just once, “You're good.” He looks around the luxurious office. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) They take sadistic pleasure in denying me that one little moment. ANALYST’S VOICE That must hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Deeply. Hitch fumbles for a handkerchief and mops his brow. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) You'll have to excuse me, doctor. I’m not used to this... process... ANALYST’S VOICE Take your time. Now Hitch claws at his tie. It’s hot in here.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: It’s just that, more and more lately, I’ve been having these... impulses. The analyst's MONTBLANC pen makes a note on a pad. We not that his hands are surprisingly coarse. ANALYST’S VOICE What kind of impulses? Finally Hitchcock is still. He stares up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Strong ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FRIDGE DOOR SNAPS OPEN to reveal Hitchcock's FACE in th darkness. He’s in his pajamas. His hand trembles next to stack of chicken breasts and moves to an upturned GRAPEFR HALF at the back of the shelf. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls it out it to reveal a hidden stash of foie gras under the hollowed out grapefruit. He’s about to devour it when he catches sight of his DISTORTED REFLECTION in the chrome shelving. He backs away, disgusted at this monster before him, the light of the fridge illuminating his expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door is quietly shut and locked. The bottom drawer of a filing cabinet is inched open. A hand rummages deep insid and teases out a bulging MANILA FOLDER. A hidden stash of some kind. The DESK LIGHT is switched on revealing HITCH. He careful extracts the contents of the folder and lays them onto th desk.

dialogues.speaker: A MASS OF PHOTOS OF ALL HIS BLONDE LEADING LADIES
dialogues.text: A personal collection lovingly kept. He settles in to stu it, picking out his favorites, arranging them in order. They're all in the same pose, all with hair pinned up int perfect bun. He looks at each image with intensifying desire. He’s cre all of them. Every detail. But it’s no longer enough...

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVES TO
dialogues.text: INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, PARAMOUNT - SAME TIME A row of HANDSOME ACTOR HEADSHOTS on a table. HITCH glare the waiting ACTORS in the hallway through the blinds. He turns back to Peggy and Alma and pulls a face.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Send them all back to Glendale. Hitch returns to the table to ponder yet more headshots. Peggy shares a glance with Alma, then slides over RODDY MCDOWELL’S HEADSHOT.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: The Lazar Office tells me he’s crazy to work with you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Well, tell “Swifty” he shouldn’t have overexposed his client on television.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Unlike certain people we could mention. Hitch ignores the barb. Undeterred, Alma pushes her ace c a photo of ANTHONY PERKINS, radiating offbeat sensitivity teen idol looks.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think of the duality he could bring to Norman. The rage lurking behind that little-boy-lost grin. The winsome charm he uses to keep from being found out.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Why, Alma, you’re not suggesting that Mr. Perkins is -- ? She raises her pinky finger just slightly. Alma nods with judgement.

dialogues.speaker: ON HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Pondering... INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, PARAMOUNT - NEXT DAY Anthony Perkins now sits across from Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY PERKINS
dialogues.text: I can’t count how many times I’ve seen Strangers On a Train and Rope.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Well, Norman is the logical extension of the boys in those movies. Appealing, sensitive, suffering the terrible burden of being forced to pretend to be something he is not. Hitchcock's deeply-felt remark lands with Perkins.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY PERKINS
dialogues.text: My only worry is that playing Norman might cut too close to home.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: How so? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch’s calmness is strangely reassuring to the young actor...

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY PERKINS
dialogues.text: I was incredibly close to my mother. So close I remember wishing my father would drop dead. And then when I was five, he did just that...He keeled over from a heart attack. (laughing nervously) You see I’ve been guilty my whole life, Mr. Hitchcock. Hitch is enthralled.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Try to remember this is all just make believe. Perkins wishes he could be more reassured...

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY PERKINS
dialogues.text: Not to be prudish, but how far do you plan to push Norman’s relationship with his mother?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Further than you can possibly imagine. On Perkins uncertain expression -- what is he letting him in for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock’s RED SWEATING FACE as he grunts and heaves. He dressed in gardening gear, laboring in the full bloom of rose garden. Alma pushes a WHEELBARROW filled with manure She shovels the manure around the rosebushes.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I'm getting blisters just looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Stop grumbling. A bit of fresh air and exercise is exactly what you need. He holds his PRUNING SHEARS menacingly over a deep red Sydonie rose. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: If I could get Grace Kelly to play the girl, they’d let me get away with anything.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Well you can’t. She's a princess now which makes her permanently unattainable. Hitchcock beheads the ROSE, muttering to himself.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: And all the more desirable. His shears are now poised over a yellow specimen.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Lew suggested Deborah Kerr.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Too... Scottish. Hitchcock cuts it too and moves on to the stem of a perfe pink rose.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: What about Janet Leigh? She’s always the ‘good girl’ but she did awfully well in Touch of Evil. Lew mentioned her name. Do you remember how you always remarked on her figure at the Wassermans' parties? As the shears hover on the stem, unsure whether to cut...

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CHASEN’S RESTAURANT - NIGHT THE SLENDER WAIST AND AMPLE BOSOM OF JANET LEIGH as she elegantly enters the dining room of Chasen’s. Hitch stands to greet her, his eyes follow her across the room in some private rapture.. Alma watches as Janet removes her glove and shakes Hitch’ hand...before he guides her to the spot to his left, acro from Alma. INT. CHASEN’S RESTAURANT - NIGHT Hitch finishes telling his story... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Of course the real secret of Mrs. Simpson's appeal to the Duke of Windsor was that she could make a toothpick feel like a cigar. He’s so deadpan... it takes a moment before she laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: You know, I’ve been so immersed in preparing to play Marion I'd almost forgotten how to laugh. Hitch summons the waiter with a snap.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Now, you must try the banana shortcake.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Nothing for me, thank you. I’m watching my figure. Alma watches all this with a fixed smile.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You’re not the only one. (to the waiter) We're fine, thank you. Hitchcock ignores Alma, gesturing to the waiter again.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Bring her the banana shortcake, George. In fact make it two large portions. He pointedly shifts to face Janet. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) So do tell me, how else have you’ve prepared to play Marion? Janet hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: I’ve written a complete history for her...It seems silly, but it helps me. She turns to pull a LEATHER NOTEBOOK from her handbag, Hitch’s gaze locks onto her silken blonde hair, tied immaculately into the classic ‘Hitchcock bun’. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: It doesn't sound silly at all. Tell me one of her deepest secrets. A quick look to Alma, as if to ask for permission before

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: She leads a double life. For instance, when she works at the Lowery office, she wears Tweed perfume. But, when she and Sam are together, she recklessly breaks out her one expensive bottle -- “My Sin” by Lanvin. She notices Alma’s expression.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But...I do have a concern or two. I’m an actress but I’m also a wife and mother first, so I’m wondering just how you’1l do that shower scene.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You and the Shurlock Office.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: It’s just... I mean even if you shoot me from here -- (she indicates a spot just above her bosom) -- well it’s not as if my figure is boyish. Hitchcock looks down at her torso, as if noting it for th first time.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Allow me to put your mind at rest. Alma reacts as Hitch reaches over and gives Janet’s hand reassuring squeeze. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) May I show you some of Mr. Saul Bass’s marvellous story boards? Hitch pulls out his folio case and shows Janet the storyboards (which we don’t see).

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I plan to shoot quick bits of film from various angles. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cut together, this montage will suggest nudity and violence but nothing will actually be shown. Janet studies them, deeply impressed. And relieved. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) And having you in the shower will make it all the more tit-illating --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: If you’ll excuse me. Alma’s had enough. Janet’s smile falters as she watches A get up and head to the restroom. She’s unsure of what jus happened but Hitch carries on regardless, either entirely oblivious or not caring at all... INT. CHASEN’S RESTAURANT, LADIES ROOM - NIGHT Alma enters and looks in the mirror, quietly devastated. looks up to find another reflection in a mirror behind he

dialogues.speaker: FULL LENGTH MIRROR
dialogues.text: Alma is SUDDENLY TRANSFORMED into a Technicolor Hitchcock blonde. In a beautiful Edith Head gown, her skin is velve perfection, her hair blonde and impeccable.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Oh, come off it, old girl. A bitchy STUDIO HEAD’S WIFE snaps Alma out of her reverie joining her at the sink to powder her face.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO HEAD WIFE
dialogues.text: Alma, dear, how lovely to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Hello Lillian.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO HEAD WIFE
dialogues.text: You're looking a little pale. No wonder with that thing your husband’s working on now. You can’t possibly approve. She's had a drink too many but the throwaway comment stil hits Alma hard. STUDIO HEAD WIFE (CONT’D) Why are you letting him do something so tasteless? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Don't upset yourself, darling. It's only a bloody movie.

dialogues.speaker: PERFECT PINK ROSEBUSHES
dialogues.text: Like in a Douglas Sirk movie. The same roses that are the ‘color’ of Janet Leigh. Alma hovers with her secateurs fo moment and then starts SNIPPING off their heads with a Caligula-like lack of mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vase of flowers, none of them pink, in the center of th table. Hitch STARES into a refrigerator filled with borin tasteless health-conscious food. Alma enters briskly and holds up a handwritten LIST.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I've made a list of places where we can tighten our belt. She places the list on the table.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It wouldn’t hurt for us all to learn the art of self restraint. Hitch goes over and picks it up, and reads.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: The gardeners only once a week and weekends off for the driver? No. Absolutely not. We’ll find other places to cut.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: There aren’t any other places. And furthermore, they’1l be no more shipments from Maxim’s either. We can’t afford it. She snatches the list out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The foie gras at Chasen’s is more than adequate.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: But those geese are from Barstow not Marseilles. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back to him.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: We all have to make our little sacrifices for the greater good, don’t we, Alfred? She leaves Hitch to resume contemplating the contents of fridge...but there’s nothing there to satisfy his growlin hunger. He SLAMS the fridge and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly we’re moving through an empty living room, prowl just like in a Hitchcock movie as we hear CLUNKING, then over to catch a glimpse of Ed as he drags A WOMAN’S BODY, feet-first up the stairs. The clunking is from her head o the steps, which is wrapped in her dress. INT. ED GEIN’S HOUSE, BATHROOM - CONTINUOUS Ed approaches the shower curtain, then yanks it open with METALLIC SCREECH. He pushes the body into the tub. Pulls dress off her head and drops it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: Stay here. I’m going to get the knives. We pan to REVEAL HITCHCOCK standing in the corner. He loo terrified but completely enthralled -- he can’t resist creeping forward for a thorough inspection. Hitch’s POV a steps closer to the tub and glimpses the woman's blood- spattered WHITE BRA and GIRDLE. Suddenly -- FINGERS CLUTCH the rim of the tub.

dialogues.speaker: DEAD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Help me. Hitch recoils but she LURCHES UP and GRABS his throat.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Ed! Ed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock bolts upright in bed, face beaded with sweat in moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Ed... Ed...? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a moment to get his bearings. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Am I making a mistake? Alma stirs in her bed. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) What if it’s another Vertigo?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up. Just get the first take under your belt you'll be fine. But Hitch isn’t looking convinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign posted outside the soundstage reads, “PRODUCTION REHEARSALS 9401. ABSOLUTELY NO VISITORS!” It only makes passing REPORTERS AND WORKERS more curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, it’s a hive of quiet purposeful activity. A.D. HI GREEN escorts VERA MILES across the far side of the stage She's 30, a classic blonde porcelain beauty in the Grace Kelly mold.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I still can’t believe you cast Vera Miles as the sister. Hitch sits in his director's chair reading a copy of the London Times.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I’ve still got her under contract. I may as well get something out of it.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Rather a thankless role, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: For an utterly thankless girl. But he still watches VERA over the top of his newspaper a the A.D. leads her through the maze of hazardous cables a light stands towards the fitting room. She passes an actor in a HIGHWAY PATROLMAN’S UNIFORM tryi on various sunglasses with the prop master. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Shurlock’'s office called again. They want to know when you'll be making the changes to the script. Hitch gets up from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: The more we frustrate them the more their interest will wane. He goes over to specify the correct sunglasses that shoul worn. The Cop puts on the MIRRORED shades. Hitch nods his approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A RAIL OF SWIMSUITS. Alma browses through them carefully. They are all perfectly nice, if a little staid Her eyes suddenly catch a COLORFUL SWIMSUIT on the end of rail. It’s striking, even a little risque. She looks at t price tag. It’s insanely expensive. She turns to go... stops... then impulsively turns back a grabs it, heading into the changing room and closing the behind her.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DARKNESS
dialogues.text: light blasts through A TINY HOLE in the wall. An EYE positions itself in front of the peephole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the VOICES of two women quietly conversing on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: HITCH
dialogues.text: Strains to get a better view.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE HOLE
dialogues.text: We catch teasing glimpses of golden girl Vera Miles strip down to bra and panties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HITCHCOCK'S EYEBALL fills the frame as he peers through t tiny hole. We reveal Vera with sharp, bohemian costumer R RIGGS, 27, who drapes taupe-colored fabric to Vera's contours. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: Break it to me gently. Am I playing a lesbian librarian?

dialogues.speaker: RITA RIGGS
dialogues.text: (re: the fabric) He chose it himself and had it imported from Paris. Vera laughs dryly at a WIG on a dummy head.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: If I wear that, I’m going to look like George Washington.

dialogues.speaker: RITA RIGGS
dialogues.text: Wait until you see the undergarments he picked out for you. Vera tosses off her shirt.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: I just have to keep telling myself, one more picture and I'm free as a bird. She unhooks her bra and crosses to hang it on a hook righ near the HOLE where we just saw Hitchcock’s eye. His eye gone, only darkness from the other side. Vera feels a chi and instinctively covers her breasts with her arm.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is there a fan blowing somewhere? Rita returns with a punitive bra and girdle.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow. The old man really is unhappy with me, isn’t he? EXT. JANET’S DRESSING ROOM, UNIVERSAL REVUE - DAY Hitch knocks at the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Are you decent my dear? JANET steps out dressed in a crisp, sexy white shirt and pencil skirt. She does a twirl for him. The effect is stunning. Even the stagehands stop to watch.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Am I alright? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His picks a tiny piece of lint on her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Perfect. As he escorts her onto the soundstage, Tony comes up to g them.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY PERKINS
dialogues.text: I want to thank you again for this opportunity, Mr. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: It's just “Hitch”, Tony. Hold the cock. Janet caught that -- she’s clearly amused. Tony gives her gracious peck on the cheek. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Look at you two. America’s favorite boy and girl nextdoor... Janet flicks a glance back at Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: And we're about to move to a whole new neighborhood. Already, Tony can’t help feel a little excluded from Hitc and Janet’s little clique. Hitch ushers them across the soundstage where the crew are assembling.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: Morning Janet. Morning Tony. Vera Miles marches up in her frumpy tweed suit and wig.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Thanks” for the wardrobe, Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: (already moving past her) That’s hand-woven imported camel hair from Rodier. Don’t you approve?

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: You're the genius. She checkmates him with a ravishing smile.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One thing, though. My script is missing the last ten pages. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Everyone's is. Until Alma finishes the revisions. Now hurry along, Vera. You're just in time for the oath.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: The what? He steers her towards a line of laughing CREW MEMBERS for a circle with the rest of the cast. He takes Janet by the hand, placing her right next to him officiously raises his right hand. The cast and crew duly follow suit, all except for Vera.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I solemnly promise...

dialogues.speaker: CREW
dialogues.text: I solemnly promise...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: (ignoring Vera’s sarcasm) That I will not divulge the plot nor the many secrets of Psycho...

dialogues.speaker: CREW
dialogues.text: That I will not divulge the plot nor the many secrets of Psycho... WE SEE VERA’S CROSSED FINGERS BEHIND HER BACK Then tilt up to Janet’s look of mock disapproval. Vera po her tongue out.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: To friends, relatives, trade reporters or columnists -- not even to outgoing President Dwight D. Eisenhower, God bless him. Everyone cracks up, but Hitchcock’s only interested in th reaction of his new blonde, standing in pride of place, r beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA sits at the desk typing away at the revisions for “Psycho.” -- we see the title page. A tiny solitary figure with nothing for company but a vas wilting flowers... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses, takes off her glasses and pushes aside her corrections, suddenly fed up with the all the work. She looks out at the swimming pool, sparkling in the sunlight... then turns to the expensive-looking SHOPPING half-open on the side... We hear a LOUD SPLASH --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Alma plunges into the water wearing her striking new swimsuit. She breaks into a front crawl. Her strokes are vigorous, surprisingly so. She drives the length of the pool, her arms slashing thro the water with increasing speed, her feet kicking out wit rising intensity... harder and harder... faster and faste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch guides Janet and Tony across the sound stage to the of Norman’s parlor.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY PERKINS
dialogues.text: Now, Hitch, explain to me why I’m watching Marion undress?

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: I feel like I should take offense at that. She and Tony laugh. Hitch’s eyes light up at this display mischief from her.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I don’t know...Perhaps as a boy, Norman secretly watched his mother preparing for her nightly bath.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Maybe there was a transom over the bathroom door?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Yes -- one he could access with a chair so long as he was stealthy.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Well, a boy’s first glimpse of a naked woman is usually his mother. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY PERKINS
dialogues.text: So...I'm reliving the past, repeating a ritual with Marion?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: You're the actor. You figure it out. Tony flinches at Hitch’s brusque response. They arrive at the set wall, where Hitch removes a painti to reveal the PEEPHOLE.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Hitch, I have a question. Why is the hole much larger on this side?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: All the better to see you at the greatest possible angle my dear... Janet simply steps up and presses her face to the hole. H studies her profile, quietly thrilled at her curiosity. T hangs back, watching Hitch watching her...

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Wow. You really do your research, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: It’s just my Jesuit work ethic. He takes a quick peek through the hole now too...then put the painting carefully back into place over it. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (PRE-LAP) (CONT’D) The truth is... I’m only happy when I’m working... INT. PSYCHIATRIST’S OFFICE, BEVERLY HILLS - DAY Hitch lies on his Analyst’s couch.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: »+. and if I’m not working then I’m nothing. I’m not even a person. I’m just a collection of molecules. A useless cylinder of ugly flesh. The Analyst circles one of his notes on a pad with his Montblanc. Again, we notice how rough-hewn his hands are. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANALYST’S VOICE (0.S.) What about your mother? Let’s go back to her.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: My mother? Yes. Hitch looks over at the unseen analyst and considers him.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She was an extraordinary person. She exposed me to Ibsen, Strindberg, Shaw. She hoped I would go into engineering -- carry a lunch pail, gold watch at fifty. ANALYST’S VOICE (0.S.) She didn't approve of your career?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: To her, movie people were akin to thieves and prostitutes. He turns back to look out the window. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) If I misbehaved, she'd make me stand at the foot of her bed and discuss how I planned to become a better boy. The Analyst leans forward and we see his dirty, worn-down fingernails. ANALYST’S VOICE (0.S.) Have you ever considered that your deep desire to gain the approval of your industry represents a textbook case of transference? (then) The Oscar is your mother.

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL THE ANALYST
dialogues.text: It’s ED GEIN. In his Sunday best, his shovel leaning agai the mahogany-paneled wall in the background.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: You're a fine one to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock leads Janet to a row of brassieres, all laid ou for inspection. They are all white with recognizable labe Berlei, Triumph, Marks & Spencer. He picks out one of the (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: You will be wearing a white bra like this for the opening scene on the bed. And then after you’ve stolen the money... They move on to a second row of brassieres - all dark.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: I switch to one of these. He nods, correct. She moves over to a mannequin displayin the iconic jet black brassiere.

dialogues.speaker: RITA RIGGS
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don’t want to look at something a little more elegant?

dialogues.speaker: HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: (sharp) No. They have to look like they were bought at Sears and Roebuck. I want every woman in the audience to look up at Janet having sex with John Gavin and think, ‘that could be me’. Janet reads the label. It’s “Maidenform.”

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: This is the brand I wear. Hitch digests the information and turns to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: We're ready for a fitting. As Rita starts to measure Janet’s chest, Hitchcock lifts hands and ‘frames’ her...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O. PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: We travel across the rooftops of downtown Phoenix and finally, through the heat, pick out a certain hotel window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Hitchcock's FRAMING HANDS as they now travel up an open window with blinds half down...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: We go under the blinds and match dissolve into the room itself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HITCHCOCK'S HANDS have now become THE CAMERA, recording t scene already underway and now watched by HITCHCOCK, his DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY and CREW from across the stage...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We pan over and discover John and Janet on the bed. ...the camera moves to Janet and John making out on the b It’s serious stuff. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) She'll be wearing only her undergarments and a large glow of satisfaction... JANET smiles up at John contentedly.

dialogues.speaker: ON HITCH
dialogues.text: watching from his directing chair. Peggy stands next to h ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Cut.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Good luck getting this one past the censor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma drives the gleaming black Cadillac through the UNIVE GATES and pulls up to the production office outside the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma collects the script pages off the front seat and wal into the production office just missing Whit as he stroll back towards the writers building with a couple of pretty SECRETARIES. Whit pauses when he spots the Hitchcocks’ CADILLAC.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: You girls go on ahead. The PRETTIEST ONE stops to make Whit light her cigarette before catching up with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy reads the final pages while Alma inspects the production boards.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: If you ask me, the credits should read “Screenplay by Joseph Stefano and Alma Reville.”

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: The people who matter know. That’s all that counts. As she makes a few more changes to the schedule. Alma tur to Peggy whose face tightens as she continues reading. Clearly it’s strong stuff.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I'd hate to see Shurlock’s face when he reads this. She puts the pages down.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alma, you always know the answer. Is this really going to work? A candid moment between the two women... but Alma doesn’t answer, just leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma emerges into the sunshine and looks across at the soundstage, wondering whether she should go over there...

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Hello, stranger. She turns to see Whit leaning against the Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Whit.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Where have you been hiding yourself?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I’ve been doing the revisions on... She points to the PSYCHO HOUSE on the ridge. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Psycho. (then) And how is the old boy?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: In a state of unbridled ecstacy now that he’s back on the set.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: And you? How are you?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Not bad. I’ve got eight hundred words to do for Reader's Digest on what it’s like to be married to a man obsessed by murder. He looks at her a moment.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: I’ve got a better idea. He steps closer. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Why don’t we drive out to Santa Barbara? We'll have Emilio fry up those juicy steaks we like at El Encanto. He playfully tugs at her sleeve. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) No shoptalk ... No silly magazine articles...just a wonderful meal... Alma’s expression gives away nothing as we pan over to th WINDOW of the production office and notice the tell-tale in the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch looks out at Whit and Alma through the window, just like he did with the other couple earlier. Except this li interaction is far from dull.

dialogues.speaker: A.D. HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: We're ready for you on the set, Mr. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I'll be right there. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Hitch doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: A.D. HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA enters the silent, empty house smiling to herself. S walks through to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and puts the grocery bags down on the counter. She list The house is eerily quiet, until, from behind --

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Was there a line at the market? Alma looks up, but doesn’t turn round, well used to Hitch cryptic ways.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: No. Actually, I'm back sooner than I expected. She puts on an apron and gets to work, preparing dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Would you like a cocktail? He heads for the liquor cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: No. (he starts to head off) And you shouldn't either. Hitchcock stops. Pulls out a CELERY STICK from one of the bags and bites it.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Those haven't been washed yet.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: (chewing) I don’t care. (then) I was filming all day with John Gavin -- a good-looking chap but, really, plywood is more expressive. His love scene with Janet may be most horrifying thing in the picture. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes another BITE, searching her face for some tell-t sign of guilt. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Even your friend Whitfield Cook would be better in the scene.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You should tell Whit that. He'd be flattered. She gets to work preparing a salad. Hitch studies the bac her tiny, vulnerable neck, the delicate sinews and muscle they rise and flex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch arranges his pillows and settles into bed while Alm finishes getting ready.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Maybe I was too dismissive about your friend Whitfield’s book. Perhaps he and Elizabeth could come over this weekend and he can walk me through it. Alma’s radar activates but Hitch continues oh-so- nonchalantly.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lovely woman, Elizabeth... He carefully folds his blanket as if wrapping a murder victim. She’s not exactly sure what he’s implying but she knows she doesn’t like it. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I was hoping you could come by the set tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I'll see how my day shapes up. She turns onto her side away from him. Pulls the blankets around her, her eyes still WIDE OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: You think you can get away with it but you can’t... Alma’s eyes become HITCHCOCK'S EYES, staring ahead intent

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: .»+. You think they can’t tell... but they can. They know. It’s all closing in on you. The noose is tightening... As he continues, we pull back and see:

dialogues.speaker: THE REAR-PROJECTION SET
dialogues.text: Janet emotes for Hitchcock’s CAMERA while “driving” a PAR CAR, being rocked by STAGE HANDS. Peggy and other CREW time and mark the takes. ELECTRICIAN AND GAFFERS turn mounted lamps that rake across Janet's worried face like car headlights. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) You could return the money secretly, but what would be the point? He wipes his brow, getting more intense...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You, Marion Crane. The prim and proper girl who’s always been so tight and respectable. So perfect and untouchable. Well, they know all about your dirty little secret, don’t they? Your messy, sticky lunchtime trysts. Yes, your boss Mr. Lowery could even smell the sex on you-- SUDDENLY THE REAR SCREEN film breaks and a frame burns. It's a good thing because Janet is starting to look a lit uncomfortable -- was that meant to be funny? As technicia yell and hustle, Hitchcock turns to Peggy -- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Circle that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Janet gets changed, Vera hangs up her frumpy coat on a rack, looking over a little enviously at Janet’s good girl/bad girl underwear hanging nearby.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: Have you talked to him much about your personal life? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Not really...

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
