dialogues.text: I'd keep it that way if I were you. (Off Janet’s look) He starts by choosing your hairstyle and clothes and then he wants to choose your friends and decide how many children you should have. Janet finds this a little hard to believe. Vera leans in, lowering her voice.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That poor, tortured soul Jimmy Stewart played in Vertigo? That's Hitch, only younger, slimmer and better-looking. That may well be true but it doesn’t bother Janet.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Compared to Orson Welles, he’s a sweetheart. They both turn, sensing something -- and see HITCHCOCK'S DISTINCTIVE SHADOW PROFILE in the hallway. The shadow lingers, then recedes like in a scary ghost story.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: (whispers) See? He's always watching. They laugh nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma comes in from her gardening, and settles on the sofa with a cup of tea, a circled copy of TV Guide next to her On television -- the 1950 Hitchcock classic Stage Fright. The credits come up: “Screenplay by Whitfield Cook, Adaptation by Alma Reville.” Alma watches, thrilled at the sight of her name and Whit’ together.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TV
dialogues.text: The words “DIRECTED BY ALFRED HITCHCOCK” overwhelm the sm screen. Alms puts down her fork, no longer hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA heads back to the kitchen, only to pause at the open door to Hitch’s study -- there’s something on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: THE HITCHCOCK BLONDES
dialogues.text: Hitch’s personal collection. Alma enters and starts to go through them. Each photo is turned over a little more rou than the last. It’s hard to tell whether she’s more angry the photos or the fact that they’ve been deliberately lef for her to find... Alma takes off an earring, picks up the phone and starts dial...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the crew prepares the car set to go again, Hitch strid over to PEGGY who’s dialing a phone.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: What’s the hold up?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: It’s still engaged. He takes the phone himself just as Vera Miles emerges fro her dressing room, script in hand.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: Hitch, I’m stuck on Lila’s first scene. I don’t know how strongly I should confront Sam and the detective and I --

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: (acidly) Fake it. He turns his back on her and dials. The ENGAGED TONE blar in his ear. His eyes narrow at some crew members fussing bits of LIGHT and SOUND EQUIPMENT. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Does it really require two men to carry a light stand?

dialogues.speaker: A.D. HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it right away, Mr. Hitchcock. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes off to fix it. Off Peggy’s questioning look.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: It's different when their pay is coming out of your own pocket. He raps the receiver button, more intensely this time, an redials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Alma’s still on the phone to Whit, basking in his cha Her feet are up. There’s a drink in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Well, I think that sounds like a fabulous idea. We’ll have a late lunch. I’1l1 make the reservation for one thirty.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: What would I do without you?

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Till then, bye. She hangs up, toying with her earring, feeling better alr when the PHONE rings again very quickly. She picks up wit even thinking --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (laughing) What did you forget now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pudgy fingers clench the coiled PHONE CORD as we move up Hitch’s face. He’s silent as a burglar, not even daring t breathe...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Whit? Is that you? The blood drains from Hitch’s face as he very slowly and carefully replaces the receiver. His mind starts to spin. He’s got to get out of there...

dialogues.speaker: CROSSING THE STAGE
dialogues.text: Hitch lurches towards the production office, starting to sweat, but his path is blocked by GRIPS laying cables. Th set is suddenly a cacophony of noise and chaos. A PR FLACK appears -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PR FLACK
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, every press outlet is driving us crazy for photos -- Hitch brushes past him to find another route but more gri are moving a ladder. He turns, kicks a platter of healthy snacks out of the way, only for an ARCLIGHT to swivel in face and blind him.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Are you okay? You’ve gone very pale. Peggy's face suddenly comes into focus.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Stop trailing me like a puppy dog and get me something long, cool and wet.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: It's not even three.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Give me the key! He snatches it and pushes past her, leaving her flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HITCH exits the soundstage doors, only to find the humorl face of BARNEY BALABAN blocking his office door.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Hitch. How’s the picture? I’m hearing interesting things...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: It’s a wonder you can hear anything over the noise coming from the Shurlock office. Balaban offers up his handkerchief. Hitchcock waves it aw even though he’s now covered in sweat.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t be in a position of just hearing things, Hitch. It’s time you showed me some footage.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Why? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: To see if you’re making a picture Paramount can actually release.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: As you well know, Barney, my contract guarantees me final cut.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: Your contract also says Paramount isn't required to distribute any film that could cause us embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Unlike the last five Martin and Lewis pictures you’re all so proud of. He slams the door in Balaban’s startled face. INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, UNIVERSAL REVUE - CONTINUOUS Hitchcock loosens his collar and catches a glimpse of him in a mirror. He’s unraveling and it shows.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I demand to see some footage, Hitch. Hitch lowers the window blinds over Balaban’s face and fumbles for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Connect me to Maxim’s of Paris. He takes the key and opens the liquor cabinet ignoring th INSISTENT KNOCKING at the door -- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) (on phone) Yes, it’s Alfred Hitchcock in Hollywood, California, Jean-Claude. I need three pounds of foie gras sent on the next flight out. (then) That’s correct. Three. He pours himself five fingers of scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A majestic view of the coastline as Whitfield Cook's Crea MERCEDES 190CL, zooms along, top down. Alma wears white- rimmed sunglasses and a head scarf. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whitfield, in true Hitchcock leading man style, has the perfect amount of wind blowing through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Those steaks haven’t changed at all, have they?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: It's so nice not to have to take care of someone, even if it's just for an hour or two. She takes in the sparkling scenery whipping past.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whit, where are we going? You still haven’t told me.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: I have a little surprise.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: A surprise. How fun. Whit just smiles as he jams the acceleration and the car ROARS off down the highway. EXT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, UNIVERSAL REVUE - DAY Hitch stands in the parking lot tapping his foot impatien near the parked Ford Fairlaine police car used in ‘PSYCHO Janet watches him, sitting behind the wheel of her VOLKSW BEETLE. After a moment she toots her horn and drives up.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: What happened to your driver?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I've been asking myself the same thing. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: I can give you a ride if you want. Hitchcock raises an eyebrow at the tiny car, and then, wi great effort inches his massive frame through the open do

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Did you know Adolf Hitler sketched the design for this car on Ferdinand Porsche's cocktail napkin in a Berlin beer garden?

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: I didn’t. She turns to see Hitch wedged uncomfortably into his seat

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: It’s only now that I truly appreciate just how diabolical Herr Hitler was. She notices him eyeing the half-eaten bag of CANDY CORN o the dashboard (the kind Norman Bates enjoys throughout “Psycho”.) ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) May I?

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Help yourself. (letting him in on it) I pinched them from Tony’s dressing room. He takes one and chews it curiously.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: So this is what they eat at the drive- ins... He takes the whole bag and sets to work, popping them in after the other.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: I thought you only ate Fauchon chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Needs must when the devil drives, my dear. He’s so deadpan but now there’s no way to tell if he’s jo or not. She puts the car into gear, sensing his despair.

dialogues.speaker: TWO PAIRS OF FEET
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nesting in the sand. Alma and Whit sit out watching the s The water laps over their toes.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I don’t mind that he uses his obsession to fuel his art. I just don’t like it when he uses it against me.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: He's like any great artist. Impossible to live with but worth the effort. (he throws a rock into the sea) Van Gogh wasn’t exactly a walk in the park either.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Did you know when we started out I was his boss? He didn’t even dare ask me out until he’d worked his way up to assistant director. Whit watches as she picks up some sand, lets it run throu her fingers...

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: What do you think of that place over there? He nods to a SMALL BEACH HOUSE up the way.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Looks nice. Terrific location. Why?

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: It's mine. She looks at him askance. Is he joking?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I just saw Elizabeth. Why on earth didn't she tell me?

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: She doesn't know about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is setting on the Hitchcocks’ driveway. The VW pu to a stop in front of the front door.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet looks over -- decides to risk it.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: So what did happen between you and Vera?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I was going to make her star. But she chose the life of a housewife. He stops chewing. We push in as his features turn reflect ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I cast her as the lead in Vertigo. Then two weeks before filming she told me was pregnant. He screws up the empty bag of candy and looks over at Jan Then, almost like a child -- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Why do they do it? Why do they always betray me?

dialogues.speaker: ON JANET
dialogues.text: As she looks across and sees the lonely abandoned little just sitting there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma enters the beach house cautiously and looks around. is old and falling apart with only a few functional furnishings.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: I'm just leasing it for the offseason. A place to get away from the wife and kid and write.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Very Bohemian.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: You might find that room interesting. Alma looks. The door is partially open -- she sees the on conspicuously new item of furniture. A double bed.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Whit. I hope you haven’t got the wrong idea. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a rakish grin, then pushes the door open fur to reveal the deck beyond.

dialogues.speaker: TWO MAUVE CORONA TYPEWRITERS
dialogues.text: Sit on a table facing each other.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: If you were serious about helping me adapt my book, I thought it would be the perfect hideaway. She lets this sink in, entranced by the incredible view a the crashing surf. Then, she steps out onto the deck and up to one of the typewriters. Gives the key an approving TAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch enters the empty house at dusk. The dogs greet him. listens a moment... then walks through to the study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch pours himself a brandy and downs it in one. He goes pour himself a second, when he notices something on the d It’s his collection of PHOTOS by the TELEPHONE. They’re a neatly stacked. With a SINGLE GOLD EARRING on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch lies in bed, his thoughts racing as he waits for Al to come home. Finally, the sound of the car comes up the driveway. He turns onto his side and pulls up the blankets, listeni to the sound of the front door ... and Alma’s footsteps d the hall. She quietly slips into the bathroom and shuts the door be turning the light on. He watches her shadow through the s of light at the bottom of door. When the bathroom light switches off again Hitch hurriedl closes his eyes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma emerges in her nightgown and stops at his bedside, peering down on him. She's not completely sure that he's actually awake, but she suspects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch eases himself up and looms over Alma to make sure s is safely asleep. He silently picks up her HANDBAG and takes it to the wind Using the moonlight he searches its contents. Car keys. Lipstick. Purse. And the first few pages of a story outline: "TAXI TO DUBROVNIK” The pages vibrate in his hand as his gaze lowers to revea the rest of the TITLE PAGE: “STORY TREATMENT BY WHITFIELD COOK & ALMA REVILLE.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GLISTENING MOUND OF FOIE GRAS spooned into Hitchcock’s mouth straight from the MAXIM’S OF PARIS tin. Hitch stand the glare of the open fridge, a beast feeding in its cave shoving in mouthful after mouthful. It’s almost pornograp in its indulgence. GEIN steps out of the shadows and puts a comforting hand Hitch’s shoulder. We hear the civilized CLINK of cutlery against china...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch and Alma sit at the table having lunch. Alma eats a pork chop while Hitch defiantly nibbles at his healthy sa He has a nice big glass of red wine which Alma ignores.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: So I read your finished treatment. “Taxi to -- " Where was it?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Dubrovnik.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: That's it. Dubrovnik. Care to hear my opinion?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Yes. Naturally. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: There’s no other way of saying it. It’s stillborn. Dead in the water. Alma blinks, unable to hide her shock.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: (with mock compassion) The plot’s a muddle. Some of the jokes are awfully like things we already did better hundreds of years ago in The Lady Vanishes. And your villain is weak. But the biggest failure is the relationship between the hero and heroine. He picks up a radish and bites into it. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) If you weren’t so smitten with your friend Whitfield cook you'd probably see that. Alma is entirely stunned. Hitchcock has delivered the kil blow he intended. He gets up and goes over to the garden door. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Women never really care to face the truth when their hearts are involved, do they? As he steps out into the garden --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: How would you know what really goes on between a man and a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch searches his pockets for his lighter but can’t find His annoyance only increases when he notices the SCATTERE LEAVES ‘contaminating’ the surface of the pool.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Look at this mess. He grabs the net and starts scooping them out. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Bloody belt-tightening. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can’t get the net into the inflow filter so he gets do on his hands and knees and starts PULLING OUT the leaves his hands.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: watches from the window... then turns away.

dialogues.speaker: HITCH
dialogues.text: Pulls out handful after handful of wet leaves, clawing aw at them like a madman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stage hands and engineers test a row of HOT WATER TANKS installed on the set. WE FOLLOW the sound of rushing water through a PIPE as it snakes across the set floor and passes through a fake wal

dialogues.speaker: A SHOWER HEAD
dialogues.text: Unleashing a stream of STEAMING HOT WATER. The SET HAND g the thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: SET HAND
dialogues.text: Tell the boss we’re ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and A.D. Hilton Green exchange a glance as Hitchcoc paces up and down in the corridor, eager to get to work.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: What’s the hold-up? Call time was two hours ago. Peggy nervously knocks on Janet's door and peers inside - INT. JANET LEIGH’S DRESSING ROOM - DAY Rita Riggs is hard at work molding MOLESKIN PATCHES to Janet's nipples.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: And you're sure this moleskin will stay put?

dialogues.speaker: RITA RIGGS
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock promised. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither woman looks convinced but they proceed with blind faith.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: It better. I’m going to be taking a shower all week. As Janet slips on her robe, a MOLESKIN TRIANGLE PLOPS ont the floor. Rita and Janet share a worried look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma sits at her typewriter while Whit stares off, lookin little uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Forget what Hitch said. He’s just feeling his age. He’ll come around.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: But he’s right. It does need more feeling. Alma ponders the problem. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: So why don’t we put some in? She gets to her feet and starts to pace...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All we need is a better catalyst. Some innocuous little trigger to release all that underlying desire. The soothing sound of the ocean gives way to the relentle HISS of SHOWER WATER --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet nervously removes her bathrobe and heads toward the MOCK SHOWER STALL.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Good morning. He takes her hand and guides her into position. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) As I explained earlier, this scene will be made up of many shots from Mr. Bass’s boards. A series of looks - actions... (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Well, you’re the professional. You’1l know how to do it. Around them, the crew frantically finalize the CAMERA and LIGHT SETUPS. MALE CREW MEMBERS look uncomfortable and excited by the unprecedented sight of a virtually nude mo star. Saul Bass comes over with his boards and Hitch and he dis the planned shot a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST A.D. HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: Tony’s stunt double is ready.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Ah. There’s our murderess. Into frame steps Anthony Perkins' FEMALE STUNT DOUBLE, MA wearing a gingham dress, silver wig and BLACK MAKEUP TO M HER FACE. She wields a large PROP KNIFE and almost blocks view of Janet in the white-tiled stall. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) (to Janet) Are you ready for our little bloodbath?

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: My mother always said, “Have confidence in yourself and you can lick anything.” Hitchcock takes Janet’s hand, and with tremendous sinceri

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: My mother used to say the same thing. (then) Let's go for a take. Quiet everyone. Over and over, Margo attacks with the knife and Janet tri deflecting the blows but both women are timid and Janet i clearly guarding her modesty and covering her body. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Cut. More intensely. Let’s go again. Margo's KNIFE comes at Janet uncertainly and every which Naked and exposed, Janet defends against the knife blows they come at her but Margo’s still pulling her punches-- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) No. More angry. You are possessed with unbridled homicidal rage. (leaping up) Cut. Cut camera. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He charges over to Margo to demonstrate the savage stabbi gesture he demands. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Does no one understand what I’m trying to accomplish here? I’m older than anyone on this stage and I’m still standing. Everyone falls silent, unsure how to respond. Hitchcock H OUT HIS HAND. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Give me the knife. Margo places the knife in Hitchcock’s palm. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Props. Bring in more blood. A FEMALE MAKEUP ASSISTANT squirts more CHOCOLATE SYRUP “blood” onto Janet from a PLASTIC BOTTLE OF BOSCO. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Roll camera. As the scene is marked, we see Hitchcock’s anxiety. There NO SOUND except Hitchcock's ragged breathing.

dialogues.speaker: CREW MEMBER
dialogues.text: Ready, sir. Hitchcock nods. The camera whirs. Hitchcock hoists the kn into the air with terrifyingly convincing power and malevolence.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHOWER CURTAIN GETS YANKED BACK --
dialogues.text: We see in the shower from Hitchcock’s POV not Janet but GEOFFREY SHURLOCK. Hitchcock SLASHES the censor a killer that sends him reeling.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHOWER CURTAIN GETS YANKED BACK AGAIN --
dialogues.text: Shurlock is replaced by BARNEY BALABAN. Hitchcock stabs h with unleashed fury and hate.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHOWER CURTAIN GETS YANKED BACK AGAIN --
dialogues.text: WHIT turns, he’s naked and smiling. Hitch plunges the kni into his back, and he drops, revealing ALMA, arms around waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back in the real moment -- JANET LEIGH SCREAMING as gives the ‘performance’ of a lifetime. Hitchcock stops stabbing. His heart pounds. He’s soaked w sweat. The only sound is the drip-drip-drip of the shower

dialogues.speaker: ON HITCH
dialogues.text: As he realizes EVERYONE is staring at him. He straightens tie, attempting to regain some semblance of control.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Print. We’ve got it. He exits quickly. Rita escorts the shaken and exhausted Janet off set, pass Vera who’s witnessed the whole thing. She’s wearing a bathrobe. Janet gives her a look as if to say ‘Now I understand.’ INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE - UNIVERSAL REVUE - CONTINUOUS Hitch shuts his office door and leans back against it. He closes his eyes, nauseated and dizzy. He doesn’t even nee open them to know who’s there, waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Not now, Ed. It’s really not a good time. He staggers towards the water cooler, fumbling for a cup. Ed steps forward and pours him some water, pats his shoul

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: You just can’t keep this stuff bottled up. But before Hitch can drink it he crashes to the floor. EXT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE - UNIVERSAL REVUE - SAME TIME Peggy and Perkins to react to the noise... HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE - UNIVERSAL REVUE - SAME TIME They come through the door to see Hitch lying on the floo He looks like he’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Oh God... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy rushes forward to help. Perkins just stands and sta as if paralysed in some Freudian nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: A TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: starts to ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is inside the beach house, and partially drowned out b the sound of the crashing waves. Alma and Whit are on the deck, acting out the scene as they write, too engrossed t notice.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: What if Helen and Michael try and get into the cab at the same time?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Even better, what if they reached for the cab door at exactly the same time? Alma demonstrates so that their hands touch.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That way, we could start close on the hands... (tracking the movement) +. and then tilt up to the eyes. They stare into each other’s eyes, lips just inches apart

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: That feels better already. Finally, the phone intrudes.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Are you going to get that? With some effort, Whit goes inside and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hullo?... Yes... Hold on. He comes outside, holding out the receiver for Alma. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) It’s for you. INT. HITCHCOCK’S OFFICE, UNIVERSAL REVUE - DAY Peggy grips the phone, her face full of concern. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I know you told me only to call in an emergency, but I’m not sure how else to describe this. Hitch lies slumped on the floor. A compress over his forehead. His head lolls to one side as he slips in and o of consciousness... FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disarray on the set. MARTIN BALSAM watches as SAUL BASS, cameraman JACK RUSSEL and A.D. HILTON GREEN argue about the best way to proceed with the staircase sequence. Hitch is conspicuous by his absence. As they bicker we find Tony Perkins off to one side, sitt in his Mrs. Bates costume, unable to cope. He puts the wi back on his head. There, that feels better... Balsam’s finally had it with all the arguing. He walks of past Peggy who’s arriving with the PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN BALSAM
dialogues.text: It's official. The inmates are running the asylum. Peggy hands Hilton the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Hilton. I have Mr. Hitchcock for you. She gives him a warning look. “Watch out. He’s in a terri mood.” He waves away her concern. It can’t be that bad.

dialogues.speaker: HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: Hey there, Hitch. We’re still working on it. (looking over at the continuing argument) Everyone misses you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch, in bed and sick as a dog, has the script, notes an boards on a bed tray. The phone receiver is pressed to hi ears. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I've told Peggy and now I'm going to tell you. You have to get this sequence shot today. What’s the hold up?

dialogues.speaker: HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: We tried it ten different ways and it looks terrible. Why don’t we use inserts?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: No. It has to be a high angle. You'll tip off the big surprise! Just get the process shot. Hitch slams down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ON HILTON
dialogues.text: Still clutching the phone, a little nonplussed. Peggy giv him a look: “What did I tell you.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma removes the phone from Hitch’s grasp. Touches his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: No more phone calls. You're burning up.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Burning up our money. We're two days behind and I’m stuck in bed. Hitch swings his legs out of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Where do you think you’re going?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: To the set. We can’t afford to lose any more time. Two more days of this and the whole production goes under. He shakily tries to get to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You stay in bed. I'11 deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I’d hate to take you away from your writing partner. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes him back against the pillows. He’s too weak to resist.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Under the blankets. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crew members sit around eating donuts. Assistant director Hilton Green and cameraman Jack Russell are still arguing over the mechanics of the shot with more crew members joi in. It’s near pandemonium. Then Alma steps in the door, and everything stops. Every member snaps to attention as Alma passes by. It's like th school principal arriving after the substitute teacher ha lost control.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Don't stop work because of me. I’m only here as one of the two people paying your salaries. Alma takes a seat in Hitch's DIRECTOR'S chair. As her eye dart around the set, it's clear that she IS TAKING EVERYT IN. Peggy flanks her.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Scene?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: One seventy three.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Storyboards? Peggy hands the boards to Alma. She and Hilton quickly re the boards.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Start with the overhead. We'll cut before the fall. Then we’ll put Martin ina chair under the camera. Hilton looks at Russell. Perfect. He sets ANTHONY PERKINS his dress into place.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the cameraman) And that lens should be a thirty-five. Peggy mouths Alma a silent “THANK YOU” for restoring orde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock lies in bed, tossing and turning, the fever onl making his thoughts darker and more obsessive.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You forgot to look in the bathroom. Hitch notices the SHADOWY FIGURE standing at the end of h bed. ED GEIN (CONT’D) A man like you... Missing the vital clue like that... He blearily sits up and sees Gein’s impassive rustic face

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Gein steps over to the bathroom and pushes open the door.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: My mother always said if you’re going to do a job, do it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock enters the immaculate white and chrome room and inspects it... but nothing seems out of place.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: Check the floor. He looks down but again, nothing. ED GEIN (CONT’D) Closer. Hitch gets down on his hands and knees. He runs his fingertips across the smooth white tiles. They start to collect --

dialogues.speaker: GRAINS OF SAND
dialogues.text: Sprinkled all over the floor. ED GEIN (CONT’D) You still think they’re just writing together? Hitchcock’s face hardens. His lip trembles. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ED GEIN (CONT’D) So what are you going to do about it? Hitch gets up, opens the medicine cabinet and takes out a BOTTLE OF BAYER ASPIRIN. He empties the tablets into the sink and very carefully, sweeps the SAND into the aspirin bottle. He caps it, slip into his robe pocket and turns off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma spots the towering figure of Balaban stride onto the stage accompanied by a MAN in a cardigan.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Barney. He sees her and bristles, clearly surprised to see her th

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: Alma. Alma takes in Balaban’s companion, and the viewfinder rou his neck.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You know David Kirkpatrick. He’s working on Jerry Lewis’ next picture. She does. They nod politely -- then stand there.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So he’s free to help... (a sly smile) if you need it... Silence. Just the bustle of crew members in the backgroun

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: That won’t be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: But you’re nearly three days behind. He takes a step towards Hitch’s empty chair, but Alma mov to block his path. It may be a small gesture, but it’s hi charged. Barney stares down at her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: Alma. We both know what kind of film this is. (then, closer) The smart thing to do would be to help Hitch finish it.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Thank you for your concern, Barney. She moves closer to him, holding his gaze, not bending on bit...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But on a Hitchcock picture, there is only one director. The anger flashes on his face as she faces him down, the entire crew behind her now, holding firm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balaban, incensed, leaves the stage with Kirkpatrick. Alm steps out into the sunlight not far behind them. As she watches them leave, she lets out a breath. A voice calls out to her --

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hitchcock? She turns to see Janet walking over in Capri pants and a sleeveless top. She’s carrying an elegantly wrapped packa

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: I hope you don’t mind. I heard Hitch was sick so I got him a little something. She hands Alma the gift. A bag of candy corn tied with a ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: That’s kind of you.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Well, he’s been very considerate with me. (a beat) I haven’t always had that from my directors.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Janet, you've been very... professional. It hasn't gone unappreciated. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma takes in Janet's unaffected natural beauty -- and he sincerity. She can’t help but notice the second glances Janet is provoking from passers-by now... She’s an impossible rival for any woman. BEETHOVEN’S 3RD SYMPHONY, ‘EROICA’ Blares deafeningly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the stereo. Alma finds Hitch on the sofa swaddled in a blanket and eating ICE CREAM.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: May I turn that down? She silences the stereo. Hitch doesn’t react.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll be pleased to know order has been restored. He still doesn’t look at her, masticating loudly.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A thank you would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: We're still two days behind and sixty thousand over budget.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I already cancelled the wrap party. That'll save us two thousand right there. And you won’t be tempted by any champagne and cake. She pulls at the bowl of ice cream. He refuses to let go.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Beware -- all men are potential murderers. She yanks it from his grip. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) With good reason. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Alright, what’s this about? He slowly pulls the ASPIRIN BOTTLE from his robe pocket, building suspense as he unscrews the lid and pours SAND i a tiny pile on the coffee table in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Spending a lot of time at the beach? He puts down the bottle, looking for a reaction.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: That’s where Whit and I are writing. He’s rented a place.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Hardly the ideal setting to avoid distractions.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Actually, it’s very conducive to creative collaboration.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I already told you -- that treatment is a waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Didn't everyone say the same thing about “Psycho”? She reaches for the ASPIRIN BOTTLE to throw it away but H grabs it first --

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Are you and Whit having an affair?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Don't be absurd. He’s working on something new and needs a little help, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: What a coincidence. I’m working on something new and I could use a little help too.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: What do you think I’ve been doing? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Then why are you spending all hours of the day and night with some overage, talentless mamma’s boy?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Because it’s fun. He quivers, livid.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I am under extraordinary pressures on this picture, the least you can do is give me your full support.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Full support? We’ve mortgaged our house. My house. Alma’s eyes flash with unaccustomed hurt and fury.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Might I remind you that I have weighed-in on every aspect of this film so far, as I have done on every picture you've done in the last three decades. And the first time you show the film, it will be my notes that you want. I celebrate with you if the reviews are good and I cry for you if they are not. I host your parties and put up with those fantasy romances with your leading ladies. And when you’re out promoting this film around the world, I will stand beside or, rather, slightly behind you, smiling endlessly for the press even when I’m ready to drop, being gracious to people who look through me as if I were invisible because all they can see is the grand and glorious “Alfred Hitchcock.” Hitchcock is stunned and silent.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, for the first time in years, I dare to work on something that isn’t “an Alfred Hitchcock Production” and I’m met with accusation and criticisms. This work I’m doing with Whit gives me pleasure and purpose. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And even though that takes absolutely nothing away from you, please consider this a reminder: I am your wife, Alma Reville, not one of the contract blondes you badger and torment with your oh-so- specific direction. She turns and, with great dignity, leaves Hitchcock sitti in the gathering gloom. He’s not the only one who can del a killer blow.

dialogues.speaker: ON HITCH
dialogues.text: with that same lost expression on his face, only now dark shadow and harsh light alternate across his features. A NAKED LIGHT BULB dangles from the ceiling as STAGE HAND prepare the film’s climactic scene in the cellar. Hitch watches as VERA reaches out to touch the shoulder o Mrs. Bates. We zoom in on her as she reacts in silent hor her HAND flying up to hit the light bulb, throwing crazy shadows all over the set. We push in on Hitchcock's face as the strobing light brie illuminates the image of -

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL BOY
dialogues.text: at the foot of his mother’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WIG on a stand. A frumpy woman’s outfit on a hangar. Ve sits in front of the mirror and unties her own hair.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: Free at last. Rita collects Vera's detested wardrobe to take back to wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks Rita. Vera rubs cold cream into her face to remove her make-up. the mirror, she sees Hitch in the doorway as Rita squeeze past him on her way out. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (wiping off her make-up with a Kleenex) Hello Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Well, Vera. You always make it look so easy.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: Oh, it was nothing, Hitch. I just faked it. She gives him a dazzlingly ambiguous Miss America smile.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I guess this is au revoir.. Hitch comes and stands behind her chair, gazing at her in mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you stay with me? I would have made you as big a star as Grace Kelly. She considers the question and the man asking it, sensing something different about him now. She continues wiping o her make-up.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES
dialogues.text: Unlike Grace Kelly, I can pick up my dry cleaning. I’ve got a family, Hitch. A home. That will always mean more to me than all of this. (then) That blonde woman of mystery you're after? She’s a fantasy. She doesn’t exist. He studies her a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: There was a time when I thought I understood you so completely -- understood women.... Hitch gives a very slight bow, touches her on the shoulde then leaves. Vera watches him go, struck by his rare show vulnerability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind blows sand off the dunes. Alma sits in the parked ca outside the beach house, contemplating the typed pages on seat next to her. An inkling that they may not be as magi as she had hoped. No matter. She checks her reflection in the rearview and applies some lipstick, readying herself. She collects the pages and heads up the steps to the deck She sees two typewriters and paper, but no sign of Whit. Something doesn’t feel right. She turns and in the bedroom, through the window, she see Whitfield Cook making love to a young woman -- it is the pretty SECRETARY from the studio lot. Alma and Whit's eye meet. Whit is horrified at being caught. Alma ducks her head, wheels around in shock. ALMA’S CAR She yanks open the door and gets in. Whit runs half dress from the house...

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: Alma, I thought you were coming later tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I thought you rented this place so we could write.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: I did. I swear -- this just happened. She struggles to get the key in the ignition. He puts his hand desperately on the car door. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) You won't say anything, will you?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I won't tell Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK
dialogues.text: I mean to Hitch. Whit smiles feebly. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) We can’t all be geniuses. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma tries to hide what a body blow this is. WHITFIELD COOK (CONT’D) Alma -- you're incredibly talented. But, after all... we want him to read the script with an open mind.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't worry about that, Whit. She starts the car and drives off. Whit watches, deflated, knowing he’s ruined everything, h receding figure swallowed up by flickering white light...

dialogues.speaker: ARE SEEING IS NOT GOING OVER WELL. NOT AT ALL.
dialogues.text: Lew sits with Barney Balaban and two executives. Lew discreetly checks his watch out of boredom. Shurlock and two Assistants look appalled. Composer BERNARD HERRMANN, 40s, prickly, sits in the back row looking suicidal. He glances back at Hitchcock who stands near the screening r door looking worse, if that could be possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurlock exits and approaches Hitchcock who’s waiting in foyer.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: You're going to have to cut all that nudity.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: What nudity? It was suggested.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: I definitely saw that knife jabbing her.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: We did no such shot.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: I'd stake my reputation on it. I'm recommending you cut the shower scene entirely. Hitchcock is livid but holds his tongue. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I'll go over it frame by frame and set up another screening. But Shurlock is already walking away... Wasserman emerges from the screening room conversing with BALABAN. Hitch searches their expressions for some indica but Balaban strides off without saying a single word to h ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) What’s the verdict?

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: Let’s just say it was a four-letter review and it wasn’t ‘good’. The harsh reality devastates Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Screw him. It's too late for Paramount to back out no matter what Balaban says. Hitch just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The other route is to recut it as a two- parter for the TV series. Because of the budget and the Hitchcock name, we stand a good chance of breaking even. Still, Hitch doesn’t say a word.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I made Jimmy Stewart a millionaire of Winchester 73 and that was a dog. At least I could sit through your picture. Hitch stares bleakly off. He can’t help noticing the KIM NOVAK-TYPE he spied on earlier outside, hand in hand and kissing her date.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: More importantly, what does Alma think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma sits with the Hitchcocks’ ACCOUNTANT going over the books again, looking at the revised figures. They close t books and sit back and look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Is there anything else we can do? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. This time he can’t bring himself to look her in eye.

dialogues.speaker: ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: We'll just have to wait and see how the movie turns out. Alma gets up and crosses to the window. Stares out at the pool reflecting a leaden sky... and the clumps of dead le floating across its surface...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Well, it is only a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs, GEOFFREY and STANLEY, lap away at a water bowl the study. A splash or two of something is added to the b from above. It’s being poured from Hitch’s brandy glass.

dialogues.speaker: HITCH
dialogues.text: pours himself another glass, leaving the dogs lapping hap away as he goes over to the Steinway Grand. There’s a ban silver-framed PHOTOS on top. He pauses to take a proper l at them. His and Alma’s life together in movies. Smiling at Premie with Cary Grant and Grace Kelly. On vacation with Jimmy a Gloria Stewart. At a black tie event with Ingrid Bergman Gregory Peck. But it’s the PHOTOGRAPH tucked away at the back that he w to see most. A BLACK AND WHITE PUBLICITY STILL taken on the set of The Mountain Eagle in 1926. He picks it up and looks at it: The young Hitchcock in front of the camera, dramatically calling “Action!” on his first film. His eyes don’t have move far to find ALMA, standing just behind him, making n on her clipboard, the same intense, serious look on her f They look so young... Hitch turns to look out the window, thoughtful -- Hitch’s POV. It’s SNOWING outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back to discover the window is now in a basement by a single oil lamp. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Gein sitting at his workbench. Hitchcock is perch on a stool nearby watching him. Trash and newspapers are piled everywhere. There is grime dark stains on the cabinets and counters.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: This is my favorite place. I just shut the doors and leave the world behind. Hitch watches Gein as he threads a needle, stitching something expertly together. He notices there’s no hint o tremble in Gein’s hands. ED GEIN (CONT’D) Pass me that bag, will you? Hitch passes over the shopping bag... then pulls up his c feeling a chill.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Don’t you get lonely out here sometimes?

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: I can always talk to my mother.

dialogues.speaker: HEADLIGHTS SUDDENLY RAKE THE ROOM
dialogues.text: As we hear CARS pull up -- a lot of them. The sound of ME shouting. Flashing RED AND BLUE LIGHTS. LOUD KNOCKING at door -- ED GEIN (CONT’D) That’s strange. FOOTSTEPS thunder above him. DOZENS OF OFFICERS are fanni out all over the house.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SCHOEPHOERSTER, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Hitch watches as Gein just sits there and the sound of SHOCKED reactions and horrified GASPS continue above... CAPTAIN SCHOEPHOERSTER (CONT’D) I think we found his hiding spot.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) They can’t go in there. That’s my mother’s room... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAR HEADLIGHTS blast through the window and Hitchcock fin sees the basement room properly for the first time; KNIVE all shapes and sizes...JARS OF PRESERVED BODY PARTS...and SEVERED HANDS, FOLDED IN PRAYER. FROM UPSTAIRS the sound of splintering wood. ED GEIN (CONT’D) They can’t go in there! (calling out) That’s my mother’s room!! Ed springs to his feet, screaming it out as he BOLTS UPST and the pandemonium continues (o.s.) WE PUSH IN ON HITCH’S FACE As the bleak reality of Gein’s lair hits him... It’s more profound and horrible than he could ever have imagined. A lush ROMANTIC SCORE starts to SWELL, mercifully drownin all out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Titles from a dark 1946 romantic melodrama fill the scree “THE SECRET HEART” “SCREENPLAY BY WHITFIELD COOK.” Alma sits watching the afternoon movie alone, brushing th dogs on the sofa next to her.

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY
dialogues.text: Hitchcock reads Alma’s fragile emotional state and enters sits down beside her and studies the screen for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: An odd little movie. Of course, Colbert is wonderful. Alma nods. They watch for a beat longer. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) How was the beach?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Cold and miserable. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Just like Barney Balaban’s face. He indicates the over-ripe dialogue coming from the TV. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Whit isn’t worth a damn when he’s not working with you. (pause) And neither am I. Alma takes in his reflective expression, but says nothing ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I didn't pull off the picture this time. It just sits there, refusing to come to life. (then) There’s no other way to say it... It’s stillborn. ALMA turns away. Hitch sits there bereft in the lonely silence. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I let you down, my love. He moves closer and takes her hand. Gives it a small sque ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) You deserved better. She still doesn’t move. After a moment Hitch gets to his feet. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I’ll go and feed Geoffrey and Stanley, shall I. He exits with the dogs padding after him. She turns back the screen and more of that stilted, mannered dialogue. Tears well in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full moon. The ONLY LIGHT from inside the house is the in the kitchen. We glimpse the figure in the window. A corpulent man in profile, like a Hopper painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch sits in his nightgown, pushing some VEGETABLES arou his plate -- his healthy midnight snack. Alma enters in her robe. Hitch watches her. She goes to t fridge, opens the PRODUCE DRAWER and from under the bruss sprouts pulls out a tiny hidden jar of BELUGA CAVIAR. She gets the crackers, a plate and a spoon and sits down the table next to him.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I don't think I can stand both of us being maudlin. She fixes several crackers, each with an appropriate doll of caviar on top, and puts the plate in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is one solution to all this, you know. She offers him one of the crackers.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We could both get to work -- together. Tentatively, Hitch accepts it.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That tiresome little Hitchcock imitation I've been helping Whit finish is done. Hitch remains quiet, delicately consuming his cracker.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I suggest, for everyone’s sake, we start whipping Psycho into shape tomorrow. You may not be the easiest man to live with but you know how to cut a picture better than anyone. Hitch puts the lid back on the caviar.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Except for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of quick shots as the editing room comes to life

dialogues.speaker: WHILE OTHERS ARE SPLICED TOGETHER.
dialogues.text: HITCH and editor GEORGE TOMASINI wait quietly like schoolboys, while Alma reviews the footage on the Moviola

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You’1l need to cut those six or seven frames where she blinks after she’s supposed to be dead.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: We've seen the footage a thousand times. She doesn't blink. Alma gives him a look ...

dialogues.speaker: FILM HANGS EVERYWHERE IN BINS
dialogues.text: FOUR ASSISTANTS are working on MOVIOLAS. Alma and Hitch w their way down the line, inspecting each new assembly.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (first moviola) Take thirty frames off the head...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: No, no, the second take, the light is better on his hands.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (next moviola) Only cut back to Janet once the car’s already moving.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Cut it tighter. The minute I lose one person I've lost the whole audience. TWO PAIRS OF HANDS. Hitchcock's and Alma's. They work lik pair of twenty-year-olds at a pair of MOVIOLAS cutting th picture. ANGLE LOOSENS -- to reveal George Tomasini has dozed off, exhausted. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You imp. You got nudity in there.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Her breasts are very large, dear. It was a challenge not to show them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Editor GEORGE TOMASINI works at the Moviola, sleeves roll up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE TOMASINI
dialogues.text: I'll be damned. She did blink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy stands with a pestering PR FLACK.

dialogues.speaker: FLACK
dialogues.text: How’s it going in there with Mr. Herrmann?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Swimmingly.

dialogues.speaker: FLACK
dialogues.text: Everyone’s saying it’s a dog with fleas. Before Peggy can deny it the argument flares through the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Absolutely not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard Herrmann is pressing his point hard with Hitchcoc

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: ...-I don’t want music in the shower murder.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD HERRMANN
dialogues.text: (frustrated) But what Alma and I talked about is really going to play.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: No. This isn’t Vertigo, Bernie. This is different. The images have to work on their own. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You can't scare people just by going, “Boo!” You have to tell them what’s coming, make them anticipate it --

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: The PR Flack shares a despairing look with Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: FLACK
dialogues.text: Thank God we've got Cinderfella for the holidays.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: BERNARD HERRMANN’S ICONIC SCORE RISES as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move across HITCH, ALMA, TOMASINI and PEGGY’S faces as they watch the Moviola. The impact of the music is instant and unimaginably power They are all moved. Gripped. Stunned. Hitchcock looks down. Peggy is gripping his arm tightly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE TOMASINI
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I think I'm never going to take a shower again.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE TOMASINI
dialogues.text: Hitch? They look at him...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: It's getting there. Alma turns to him and Hitch nods slightly. Was that the tiniest acknowledgement that her instinct may have been right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SHURLOCK’'S HUMORLESS FACE Hitchcock sits opposite him at the big conference table. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: I told you, I distinctly saw both the stabbing and the nudity. We're denying your seal, Mr. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I take your opinion very seriously. But what you think you're seeing is purely informed by the power of suggestion. I assure you that once you view the final version with Mr. Herrmann's lovely, lyrical score...

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: A “lyrical score” won't change my opinion. All that innuendo and half-naked groping -- really, Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Would you mind if we had a word in private, Geoffrey? Shurlock gestures his staff out. Hitch moves closer. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I have a modest proposal to make. If you're willing to leave the shower sequence as it is, I will reshoot the opening love scene to your exact specifications. Shurlock reacts with surprise. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) In fact, I'd welcome your personal supervision on the set. Shurlock is more flattered than he’d care to admit.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: My specifications?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: If only audiences could fully appreciate how tirelessly you work to help us entertain them while protecting them from filth and indecency. Shurlock studies Hitchcock’s sphinx-like expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock and Peggy confer. John Gavin and Janet Leigh, wearing robes, chat while lying on a bed. Crew members wa impatiently. Peggy checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: He's been harassing you since you announced this project, you invite him to the set, and he doesn’t even show up? What did you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: That I respected him. Deeply. Peggy laughs. Now she understands. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Ladies and gentleman, that is a wrap. Thank you all. The crew starts breaking things down. The actors are baff Janet walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: I thought we were reshooting the scene.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: No need. The charade is over. Hitch holds out his arm for her and walks her back to the dressing room. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) See, I wasn’t that much of a monster to work with, was I?

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH
dialogues.text: Not at all. He offers his hand and she shakes it, determined to be professional to the end.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just hope I was sufficiently loyal to the cause.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Worthy of a Purple Heart, my dear. She leans in and gives him a peck on the cheek. A moment unexpected heaven that leaves Hitch speechless. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away to her dressing room. Hitch watches as she steps inside and closes the door. After a moment we hear a PIERCING SCREAM -- INT. JANET LEIGH’S DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS Janet recoils at the sight of A MRS. BATES PROTOTYPE “PRO MASK" grinning lewdly from her chair, and wearing one of Janet's brassieres. Hitchcock peeks inside as crew members come running.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I hope you don’t mind, I told Mrs. Bates she could have your dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: ON JANET
dialogues.text: She can’t believe she’s been caught out. She closes the d on everyone... and then after a moment SCREAMS AGAIN... b this time not out of shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch sweeps in. Lew is waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: We have our seal from Shurlock’s office. (devilishly) Now, we lead the lambs to the slaughter. Hitch turns to Lew for the latest news.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: The front office confirmed. They’re only opening the movie in two theatres, as we suspected. And no premiere. If we don’t get word of mouth we’re dead.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Then we'd better get started. Peggy, take a memo... Peggy whips out her steno pad. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) We're going to write a manual on exactly how to sell Psycho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOKLETS make the rounds on a conveyor-like contraption. the booklets are bound by swift-moving WORKERS, we see Hitchcock's photo on a cover and his “advice” to theater owners.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My first instruction to Theater Owners: Hire Pinkerton guards to strictly enforce our unique admission policies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MANAGER opens up his PSYCHO PROMOTIONAL HANDBOOK and st to read, totally baffled.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Furthermore, because Psycho is so terrifying and unique, the guards can help you deal with customers who run amok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager introduces the PINKERTON GUARDS to his equall bemused STAFF.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Post our special lobby clocks to remind audiences of the starting times for Psycho. He oversees as they hang a ridiculously large PSYCHO CLOC the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch’s voice booms from LARGE SPEAKERS MOUNTED UNDER THE MARQUEE.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The manager of this fine motion picture theater has been advised not to allow anyone to enter the theater once Psycho begins. We PAN DOWN to the STAFF and GUARDS as they test out the RECORDED message that will be played for the ticket holde line. A couple of PASSERSBY listen, perplexed... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALFRED HITCHCOCK (V.0O.) (CONT’D) Should you be so foolish as to attempt to slip in by a side entrance...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: .»+. a fire escape or through a skylight, you will be ejected by brute force. Hitch lays down the track into a large microphone while A watches from the recording desk.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: More playful, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of life-size HITCHCOCK STANDEES are carried in thro the door one by one. Posters are hung in the theatre lobb The letters hoisted up and hung on the marquee outside.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “To further emphasize the sheer, unrelenting shock and suspense of Psycho, right after the closing title “THE END,” we strongly recommend that you close your house curtains over the screen for a full thirty seconds.” Inside the theatre, the manager makes sure the CURTAINS o and close correctly then turns to face the vast, empty auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: “By doing so, the horror of Psycho will be indelibly etched in the mind and heart of your audience.” He anxiously surveys the hundreds of seats that will have be filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Barney Balaban is reading Hitchcock's publicity manua the board. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN
dialogues.text: “Absolutely never, ever will I allow anything to follow Psycho -- no previews of coming attractions, no newsreel, no short subject and certainly no double- feature. Sincerely, and, emphatically, Alfred Hitchcock.” Balaban shuts the pamphlet. Silence. Then turns to the st faced board members : BARNEY BALABAN (CONT’D) At the end of the day, it’s a minor Hitchcock movie. One week, and it'll be gone... He tosses the pamphlet into the trash.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like a bad dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON HITCH AND ALMA’S SILENT TENSE EXPRESSIONS as they driv through the frenetic madness that typifies Times Square, 1960.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DAZZLING MARQUEE for “ALFRED HITCHCOCK'S PSYCHO.” The c pulls up. Hitch and Alma step out. There’s a long line of people outside the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Well, at least there are some people here. But Hitch’s nerves are hardly soothed. The people in line start to notice the Hitchcocks...is it really them?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Comes over to greet them with the THEATRE MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: We can go through the side entrance. As the theatre manager ushers them through the side alley (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: THEATER MANAGER
dialogues.text: Right this way, Mr. and Mrs. Hitchcock. Hitchcock turns to Alma.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Ready for the gallows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is tense as people hurry to their seats. L greets them.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: We've roped off some seats for you.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: You go on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I‘1l join you in a minute. Off Alma’s look. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I want to double check the print.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Fine, darling. I'll save you a seat. Lew escorts Alma and Peggy into the auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soothing whir of the projector as Hitchcock stands ne to it... but the sound of the audience below TITTERING NERVOUSLY is anything but reassuring.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: (under his breath) But they’re laughing too much. He peers down through the tiny window but can’t see a blo thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch inches open the door and PEERS THROUGH THE CRACK at audience but now he can’t read them. Are they gripped wit suspense -- or do they just hate it? From the lobby we see

dialogues.speaker: HITCH
dialogues.text: as he closes the door and leans back against the wall of empty corridor. A scared, lonely, corpulent figure. Total powerless. There’s nothing for him to do but wait. And wait. And wait. Across the foyer, a spotty young THEATRE EMPLOYEE sweeps ticket stubs and empties ashtrays, quietly going about hi business, entirely oblivious... ON HITCH’S FACE As he grips the railing. This is taking far too long. And then -- finally -- the sweetest sound in the world A BLOOD-CURDLING SCREAM. Soon the WHOLE AUDIENCE SCREAMS IN TERROR... then breaks LAUGHTER again... nervous laughter this time, the best ki

dialogues.speaker: HITCH
dialogues.text: As he gestures with his hands, a conductor leading his orchestra, raising them up again as the audience STARTS SCREAMING AGAIN right on cue

dialogues.speaker: PUSHING TIGHTER ON HITCH
dialogues.text: As the dam breaks and all the pent-up emotion floods out. leaving only relief and satisfaction... and making way fo smile... the largest of his whole career.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch, Alma and Peggy are led out into the foyer by the theatre manager. There are still SCREAMS in the theatre a the show continues. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lew can be seen on the phone in the theatre manager’s off in the background as Hitch, Alma and Peggy walk past the of ticket buyers to get to the front doors. There is grea excitement now as more and more people recognize the Hitchcocks...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN WAITING ON LINE
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, how does it end?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: I promised Mother I wouldn't tell. He gets a laugh. Hitchcock walks alongside the Theater Manager who’s not going to miss out on having his own mom with the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: THEATER MANAGER
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, what do I do now that my wife won't take a shower after seeing your movie?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Have her dry-cleaned. Laughter as Lew appears.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with Balaban. I couldn't resist telling him we’re sold out for the next two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: He said “Tell Hitch congratulations. A well deserved triumph as we always knew.”

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: “As we always knew...” The two friends a look.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Does this mean I can take the weekend off now? Hitch playfully shrugs, “we’ll see”.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRE MANAGER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mr. Hithcock but there are photographers outside. They heard you were here. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The theatre manager ushers them towards the exit doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few photographers snap Hitch as he emerges and heads pa the line of ticket buyers towards the waiting car. Hitchc gestures for Alma to take her place next to him instead o behind him. She shyly waves him away but eventually, and appreciatively, relents. As the flashbulbs start to POP --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: This could be the biggest hit of your career, Alfred.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: Our career, Alma. He looks into her eyes with nothing but deep, intense gratitude and joy. As more flashbulbs pop -- ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) I’ve realized I’1l never be able to find a Hitchcock blonde as beautiful as you.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You do realize I've been waiting decades to hear you say that. He gives her a gentle peck.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: And that, madame, is why they call me “The Master of Suspense”... He helps her into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a utilitarian institutionalized dining room. Severa nonviolent INMATES eat at different round tables around t room. An ATTENDANT watches, and an ORDERLY mops the floor (ther are NO female patients nor staff members.)

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL ED GEIN
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is at a table with two other patients, including a soft spoken older man, CHET. Ed is heavier, his hair is whiter and he is much more at ease than we've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: (to the Attendant) Guess what I'm doing this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Claudine and I are driving to Chicago with her folks to see that Psycho movie. The Attendant pulls the orderly aside, and whispers to hi nodding toward Ed. The Orderly's jaw drops! It is the coo thing he's ever heard. He looks at Ed like he's a movie s Meanwhile, Ed yawns, content. Utterly oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I think you're the happiest guy I've ever known, Ed. How you do it?

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN
dialogues.text: I‘1l tell you. You live your life, and it's unbearable sometimes but there's this secret, Chet; a big secret no one else knows or wants to tell... (he leans a little closer) «+. there is a God and he’s so big and powerful, he doesn’t always remember you're there... He takes a huge bite blueberry pie. ED GEIN (CONT’D) .»+. but if you can get his attention and he sees you're suffering, he’ll notice and he'll take care of you. My mother used to tell me -- she’s passed, God bless her -- the one thing God truly loves and understands is suffering. He takes a long drink of milk.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After all, he invented it. We pan to discover HITCHCOCK has been watching all this. turns to the camera. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: And so, gentle viewer, Psycho -- the picture everyone predicted would bring me to wrack and ruin -- was such a hit that Alma and I got to... Well, let’s just say that we got to keep our house -- and the swimming pool. And the same critics who despised it went on to call it one of my greatest achievements. He produces a CIGAR and wanders towards the exit doors. ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Of course for me, it was just another “moo-vie.” As he strolls through the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and seamlessly appears in the beautifully tended garde as if having walked through a portal.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK
dialogues.text: But you know what they say in Hollywood: “You're only as good as your last picture.” So, now, if you'll excuse me, I must toddle off to begin the exhaustive search for my next project. He holds out his cigar towards something we don’t yet see ALFRED HITCHCOCK (CONT’D) Unfortunately I find myself once again bereft of all inspiration. I do hope something comes along soon...

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL BIRD
dialogues.text: Alights on his cigar tip and FLAPS its wings. Hitchcock c resist blowing a sadistic plume of smoke at the bird whic promptly flies away. He gives the camera a final characteristically deadpan look...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good evening. The distinctive THEME TUNE to his TV show starts up and H toddles back up the front lawn and toward the terrace, wh Alma can be seen laying out a delicious healthy lunch...

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ACCEPTED THE AMERICAN FILM INSTITUTE'S LIFE ACHIEVEMENT
dialogues.text: AWARD, HE DEDICATED THE HONOR TO HIS WIFE, SAYING, “I SHA MY AWARD, AS I HAVE MY LIFE, WITH ALMA.” FADE OUT.
